Command the Heavenly Lord of Harmonious Advent from the Lower Realm, with the divine immortals, celestial troops, and innumerable hosts of the famous mountains and grotto-heavens, to descend and shield those who uphold this scripture.

The Jade Emperor proclaimed: Upholding the scripture is not merely reciting it with the mouth. If any being in the world honors and serves their parents, reveres the Dao, scriptures, and masters of the Three Treasures, exhausts their strength and whole heart in utmost loyalty to their sovereign, refrains from killing, stealing, or licentiousness, forsakes jealousy, anger, resentment, arrogance, and deceit, receives and observes the pure and mysterious precepts of the Daoist canon, maintains true and proper fasting, avoids negligence and impatience, abides in tranquility and equanimity, silently follows nature, nurtures the spirit in stillness, models themselves after Heaven to solidify their true nature, contemplates the Great Dao with a profound mind, reveres the August Heaven as if it were present, and holds the Dao and its scriptures in esteem and veneration—

It is also said: One must cultivate strict reverence without carelessness, uphold, recite, and chant this scripture.

*I, the Jade Emperor, speak of myself. Read as "We."*

Then command the dispatch throughout all worlds and Dharma realms, transmitting across the boundless worlds in the ten directions. Command the Eastern Emperor Lord of Azure Radiance, the Azure Rider; the Southern Great Emperor of Vermilion Mound, the Crimson Rider; the Western August Numinous Sovereign Elder, the White Rider; the Northern Emperor Lord of Purple Tenuity, the Black Rider; and their divine immortals and celestial troops.

The Southeastern Great Emperor of Fusang, the Southwestern Primordial Elder of Great Flower, and the Northwestern August Heavenly Thearch belong to the Qian direction. The Northeastern Heavenly Lord of Impenetrable Void and the Supreme Heavenly Thearch of the Upper Realm—this is not the Celestial Thearch of the Curved Array, but the deity who governs Heaven. *The Buddha calls him the Heavenly Lord Śakra.* The Yellow Rider of Kunlun’s Ancient One and the Heavenly Lord of Harmonious Advent from the Lower Realm, along with the divine immortals, celestial troops, and innumerable hosts of the famous mountains and grotto-heavens, are all commanded to descend and shield those who uphold this scripture.

*To shield: to protect, cherish, and uphold.* Those who uphold the scripture respect and honor the words of the Emperor and the Dao, aligning their virtue with Heaven and the Dao to merge with the true. They embody the Great Dao. Where the Dao resides, both gods and humans revere it; thus, the Emperor commands the sacred hosts of the ten directions to shield them. Yet this applies only to those who are loyal, filial, reverent, and observe the precepts against killing, stealing, licentiousness, and deceit.

Upholding the scripture is rooted in virtuous conduct. Contemplate the Dao with a profound mind, and the Dao will naturally return to you. Some say that Daoists who leave the household do not draw near to sovereign or kin, deeming them disloyal and unfilial. Yet they do not understand that the mysterious precepts of the Daoist gate are most strict—those who observe and cultivate them dare not violate the precepts, lest they harm their bodies and shame their kin. With utmost sincerity and firmness, they first repay the Four Gratitudes. How could they ever forget their sovereign or kin, or fail in loyalty and filial piety? Thus, the Perfected Lord Xu permitted the *Scripture of Pure Brightness on Loyalty and Filial Piety* to reveal the true loyalty and filial piety of the Dao.

**Chapter Three of the Protective Upholding**

Command all Golden Immortals of the ten directions, the Four Assemblies, the Eight Divisions, and all their retinues to descend and shield those who uphold this scripture.

Command all Heavenly Perfected Great Sages, Flying Heavenly Divine Kings, the Three Officials, the Four Saints, the Two Luminaries, the Nine Stars, the Northern Dipper, the Southern Dipper, the Eastern Dipper, the Western Dipper, the Central Dipper, the Twenty-Eight Constellations, all the stars of the celestial sphere, the Vajra Warriors, the Divine Kings, and their respective hosts to descend and shield those who uphold this scripture.

Command all Golden Immortals of the ten directions across the worlds. The Golden Immortals are the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. The Four Assemblies are not the Four Assemblies of the mundane world, but the Four Assemblies of yin-yang spirits, divine generals, and soldiers. The Eight Divisions are explained in the second fascicle. And their retinues refer to the kin and followers of the Four Assemblies and Eight Divisions. The Heavenly Perfected Great Sages of the ten directions are the Great Sages among the hosts of Perfected Ones in the ten directions. The Flying Heavenly Divine Kings are explained previously. The Three Officials are Heaven, Earth, and Water. The Four Saints are Heavenly Marshal Peng, Heavenly Marshal You, the Illustrious Sage, and the Protective Sage. The Two Luminaries are the sun and moon. The Nine Stars are Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth, Moon Comet, Purple Qi, Rāhu, and Ketu. The Northern, Southern, Eastern, Western, and Central Dippers are the Five Dippers. The Twenty-Eight Constellations are Horn, Neck, Root, Chamber, Heart, Tail, Winnowing Basket, Dipper, Ox, Girl, Emptiness, Rooftop, Encampment, Wall, Straddler, Bond, Stomach, Mane, Net, Turtle Beak, Orion, Well, Ghost, Willow, Star, Spread, Wings, and Chariot, along with all the stars of the celestial sphere. The Vajra Warriors, Divine Kings, and their respective hosts are all the generals and their divisions. Each with their respective subordinates. Verification:

By imperial decree, this scripture is promulgated by the court’s command. The Three Dukes, Four Ministers, officials of the Two Capitals and Nine Courts, all functionaries and attendants, noble kinsmen and foreign clans, the myriad multitudes of black-haired people—none fail to revere and uphold it. Those who receive and maintain this Jade Scripture under the shelter of the host of spirits do so by imperial mandate to honor the worthy and assist the virtuous.

Within the human body reside the Three Origins, Four Symbols, Two Qi, Nine Palaces, Five Phases, and the degrees of the Twenty-Eight Constellations. The warp and weft of the celestial sphere, the waters and fires of true resolve, great wisdom, cultivation of conduct, vigorous practice, wondrous Dharma, and meritorious deeds—together with the host of spirits—constitute the entirety of a person. From the body’s hair and skin to its flesh, blood, and marrow; from its sinews and bones to its spirit and qi; from its essence and radiance to its meridians and collaterals, all serve to sustain our true qi of correct nature, wherein the treasure of life is preserved.

This true qi of correct nature is none other than the imperial true scripture. The thirty-six thousand spirits and qi, the eighty-four thousand luminous pores—these are the immortals and perfected beings of the ten directions, the Vajra Warriors, stellar deities, and divine kings with their legions. As the *Scripture of Disaster Dispelling* states: “There are hundreds of millions of celestial perfected beings and Vajra Warriors who guard and protect this scripture”—such is its meaning.

The scripture does not reside in words or written signs; its true import lies within our hearts. The spirits do not dwell in the ten-directional worlds but within our very selves.

To cultivate the heart and refine the body does not lie in recitation or perusal, but in silent operation with utmost sincerity, free from self-interest. When spirit, essence, and qi are whole, sageliness may be learned, Heaven may be aspired to, and the Dao may be entered—every movement shall be auspicious, and the spirits will surely protect one. If the Three Treasures are depleted and the One True [Nature] is lost, one’s own spirits wane and qi weakens, essence fails to flourish, and one falls into opposition with Heaven—how could the spirits protect such a one?

Alas, all are human: the noble one cultivates and meets with fortune, while the petty one rebels and meets with misfortune. Thus the scripture states: those who uphold and protect this scripture shall know that Heaven bestows blessings upon the virtuous. The imperial virtue is boundless, and the scripture’s benefits are supreme—it depends solely on how one reveres and receives it.

**Chapter on Protection and Upholding (IV)**
By imperial decree, the Vajra Warriors of Subduing Demons, the Four Heavenly Gate Kings, the deities of the Five Marchmounts and Four Waterways, all renowned mountains, the Four Seas and Nine Rivers, the Twelve River Sources, mountains and forests, rivers and marshes—all their lords and retinues—are commanded to shelter and protect those who receive and uphold this scripture, ensuring their safety in all perilous places.

By imperial decree, all local earth spirits, ditch and canal deities, and all mighty ghost kings are commanded to shelter and protect those who receive and uphold this scripture.

The Twelve River Sources are here recorded as thirteen names, for two waters share a single source—hence they are called the Twelve River Sources.

By imperial decree, the Demon-Subduing Kings and Heavenly Ding Warriors are commanded.

The Four Heavenly Gate Kings are the kings of the eastern, southern, western, and northern heavenly gates. The Five Marchmounts are Mount Tai in the east, Mount Heng in the south, Mount Hua in the west, Mount Heng in the north, and Mount Song in the center. The Four Waterways are the deities of the Yangtze, Yellow, Huai, and Ji Rivers. All renowned mountains in the world are included. The Four Seas are the eastern, western, southern, and northern seas. The Nine Rivers are the Yangzi, Qiantang, Hanshui, Xunyang, Huntong, Jinjiang, Xiangjiang, Wulong, and Yalu, along with all other rivers. The Twelve River Sources refer to the Yellow River as the world’s pulse—its origins include Kunlun, Yumen, Star Constellation Sea, Huodunnao’er, Weilu, and the sources of the Faxie River. Another account states that the Yellow River’s source at Kunlun has nine wells and seven springs, not merely twelve. The Twelve River Sources refer to Yu’s dredging of the Nine Rivers, along with the Ru, Han, Huai, and Si Rivers, totaling twelve. The Nine Rivers are the Tuhai, Taishi, Majia, Fufu, Husu, Jianjie, Goupan, Gejin, Ru, Han, Huai, and Si—these are the Twelve River Sources. The Yellow River is the general spirit of all rivers. Rivers such as the Jing, Wei, Yi, Wen, Zhen, Wei, Hutuo, Xingqia, Weak Water, and all others are its tributaries.

Mountains and forests encompass all in the world. Rivers and marshes encompass all in the world. Flowing waters are called *chuan*; marshes are watery expanses. "All lords" refers to the spirits presiding over mountains, forests, rivers, and marshes, along with their retinues, who shelter and protect those who receive and uphold this scripture. In all dangerous and treacherous places, they ensure safety and stability for those who uphold the scripture.

Wherever the imperial decree reaches, all local earth spirits and responsive numina, along with ditch and canal deities—where a ditch is a waterless channel, whether in mountains or earth, and a canal is a water-filled channel—and all other minor spirits, as well as all mighty ghost kings, are commanded to shelter and protect those who receive and uphold this scripture.

The scripture’s dharma decree is revered by all immortals, upheld by all buddhas, practiced by all heavens, venerated by all spirits, and recited by all people—even demonic forces submit of their own accord. Truly, mountains are thus stilled, waters thus flow long, and protection is thus strict. Since those who uphold the scripture are guarded by all spirits, how could they dare be negligent? A single lapse brings profound transgression and grave offense.

How well Confucius said: "The petty person does not know the Mandate of Heaven and thus does not stand in awe of it." To treat the great with familiarity, to mock the words of sages—such is the petty person. In viewing this scripture, one must still take warning and exert oneself.

**Chapter on Protection and Upholding (V)**

Let all demonic heresies be utterly subdued, their forms concealed and traces hidden, soaring high beyond the seas or fleeing far to other lands. Thus shall the spirits of mountains and forests, altars of the earth, and temple deities that partake of blood offerings all vanish of their own accord. The plague-bearing demon marshals of the five directions, all malevolent spirits, wind kings and water monsters, sinful dragons of karmic clamor, earth sprites and water specters—all shall dissolve away. The fivefold emptiness and sixfold depletion, disturbances in dreams, wild curses, hexes, and poisons—all shall dissipate on their own. For those who uphold this scripture, every desire of the heart shall be fulfilled, every wish granted in full.

*[Note: 慑 is pronounced "nie."]*

"Let all demonic heresies" refers to the command to subdue and eradicate them. "Demonic heresies" include heavenly demons, earthly demons, demon kings, demon folk, and demon women. "Heresies" encompass lewd doctrines, heterodox teachings, deviant practices, miscellaneous arts, and lesser techniques—such as the three thousand six hundred private methods, the ninety-six schools, and the thirty-six thousand varieties. "Let" signifies the imperial decree to suppress and eliminate them, ensuring all are thoroughly subdued.

All—this means entirely. *Nie* (慑) signifies awe and reverent submission. *Fu* (伏) denotes restraint and yielding compliance. They conceal their forms and flee their traces. *Qian* (潜) means to hide, concealing their shapes so they dare not appear. *Dun* (遁) means to evade, escaping their shadows so they dare not linger. Though the forms of these demons may outwardly seem enchanting, their illusions strangely beautiful, their true nature is obstructive and cannot be shown to others. The true methods of this scripture shatter the courage of ghosts and crush the hearts of demons; no demon can escape its scrutiny. Fearing the profound power of its divine teachings, they dare not remain, lest their foul essence be exposed. The words of heterodox teachings seek to confuse the truth. Yet when the true Dao is practiced, deviant doctrines fade; when the great Way is revered, lesser paths are abandoned. Once the imperial decree is proclaimed, none dare harbor them. They soar beyond the seas, their demonic ways leaving no trace—this may be described as "flying." But how can heterodox teachings "fly" upon entering the ear? They transform the heart and alter thoughts, turning toward the Dao and forgetting self-interest. "Soaring beyond the seas" is a common expression, akin to "the soul flying beyond the heavens" or "the spirit scattering to the nine skies." They flee to distant lands, daring not remain in their former abodes.

Thus, all spirits of mountains and forests, altars to earth and grain, shrines and temples, and those who partake of blood sacrifices shall dissipate on their own. *Mountains and forests*—explained previously. *She* (社) is the earth deity; *ji* (稷) is the grain deity. *Ci* (祠) means to administer or to sacrifice, where the spirit presides and is invoked in prayer. *Miao* (庙) means to attend, where spirits are honored in the temple with morning rites—those who receive offerings of blood and sacrificial wine. These are all spirits deemed worthy of worship, yet how can they be made to dissipate on their own? Spirits that demand sacrifices must be unjust; people who flatter spirits must be unrighteous.

Thus, Master Sa the Perfected subdued Marshal Wang Lingguan and reformed the forbidden city gods; when Ximen Bao governed Jizhou, he cast the witches into the river to restrain the river deity. How much more, then, when evil spirits falsely assume divine forms to delude people, and people revere such evil to deceive the world? When Hu Ying administered Guangdong, he destroyed illusory Buddhas, slew the serpent demon, and beat the monks to liberate the foolish masses from their delusions. Now, it is said that all ghosts and spirits shall dissipate on their own—those who uphold this scripture’s decree shall neither invite misfortune nor fortune, and shall dwell in peace, free from threats or clamor.

The plague-spreading demon marshals of the five directions, all malevolent ghosts and spirits—whether the fierce ghosts and overbearing deities of the world, the wind-controlling kings, the aquatic monsters, the violent dragons, the perverse and inauspicious spirits, the earth spirits and tree specters—shall all vanish of their own accord. The five deficiencies and six depletions—where the five viscera (spirit, qi, blood, and body) grow weak, and the six pulses decline—shall cease, along with disordered dreams and restless souls. Alternatively, the five deficiencies and six depletions refer to celestial omens like Heaven’s Wailing and Ruin, along with baleful stars such as Sangmen, Tai Sui, Great Depletion, Lesser Depletion, Fei Kang, Kong Wang, Yellow Pennant, Leopard’s Tail, Nine Fruits, Red Mouth, White Tongue, and the malevolent spirits of curses, oaths, hexes, and poisons—all such base practices, heterodox ways, incantations, and demonic speech, whether cursed or sworn, shall likewise dissipate.

For those who uphold this scripture with sincere devotion, all desires and aspirations shall be fulfilled as their hearts wish, without hindrance or opposition. The virtuous and those who walk the Dao command the reverence of ghosts and spirits, while all inauspicious and perverse forces are dispelled. Witness the death of the ominous mulberry, the expulsion of pestilence by the catalpa staff, the subduing of the flood dragon by Zheng Yang, the vanquishing of demons by the Celestial Master, and the binding of ghosts by the Sa Patriarch—all these bear clear testament. Alas, Wang Yanfang was a man of valor; even bandits, when sentenced to execution, dared not let Yanfang learn of their heterodox ways, for his virtue was as resounding as a bell.

Yet the three corpses, five burdens, seven emotions, six desires, and nine consciousnesses within a person—when these lower evils wreak havoc, they deceive one into failing to correct oneself, allowing perverse forces to persist and inauspicious influences to linger. If one can rectify their path, sever the three corpses, eliminate the five burdens, purge the emotions and desires, and expel the nine consciousnesses’ evils, then their personal aspirations shall be fulfilled, external perils shall vanish, and misfortune shall scatter while fortune arrives.

**Chapter on Upholding the Six Precepts**
Even those who cannot yet follow the ritual codes and observe fasts or jiao offerings may still uphold purity and precepts, maintain unwavering faith, and revere this scripture with devotion—such persons are equal to those who perform the fasts. Those who uphold pure precepts shall find their merit unimpeded, their virtue unobstructed, and they shall be called sages among men, their wisdom and power ever-renewed, akin to the perfected immortals.

For those who receive and uphold this scripture in accordance with the Dao, their merit shall be immeasurable. Even if one cannot yet follow the profound ritual codes and perform grand jiao offerings, so long as they maintain purity without defilement, uphold the precepts with single-minded devotion, and observe the Daoist commandments—whether the Five Precepts, Eight Precepts, Twelve Precepts (as appropriate), Eighteen Precepts, Twenty-Four Precepts, Thirty-Six Precepts, Seventy-Two Precepts, One Hundred Twenty Precepts, One Hundred Eighty Precepts, Three Hundred Great Precepts, or the Six Hundred Pure Precepts for female Daoists—if they focus their will, uphold these precepts with unwavering resolve, and revere this scripture with sincere faith, they shall be counted among those who perform the fasts. Those who uphold pure precepts in this way shall find their merit unimpeded.

Even those who cannot yet follow the ritual codes, perform fasts or jiao offerings, or maintain purity while revering the scriptures—if they can uphold purity, maintain single-minded faith, and revere this scripture with devotion—are all equal to those who perform the fasts and uphold pure precepts. The merit of those who cannot yet follow the ritual codes but perform fasts or jiao offerings, or those who revere the scriptures with purity, is the same. The gods shall respect and protect those who uphold these pure precepts.

Alternatively, if one maintains purity and single-minded devotion in upholding their precepts, their merit shall be unimpeded. "Unimpeded" means level and vast. If the heart is divided, merit cannot be genuine. If precepts are not upheld, merit is tarnished. When body and mind are pure, precepts are upheld with devotion, faith is sincere, the scripture is revered, the heart is undefiled, and resolve is unwavering—without deficiency or hindrance—then merit is true and naturally unimpeded. What obstacle could remain? They shall dwell in freedom and ease.

Human nature is born free and unconfined. Yet beset by worldly cares and material burdens, one toils in ceaseless hardship, no longer at ease—how can there be joy? With purity and right faith, free from material burdens, one attains great freedom, ever joyful and carefree. Such a one is called a sage among men—not merely a carefree person. With purity and right faith, rising above the common throng, they are called a sage among men. Their virtue and wisdom ever renew, cultivated with growing insight; transformation aligns with the heart, perception is true and wisdom profound, worldly burdens fade and true nature abides in clarity. Virtue daily renews, wisdom daily brightens—this is virtue and wisdom ever new. Together with the perfected ones—those of pure and right faith who uphold the scriptures and attain the Dao, the celestial perfected—such is the meaning of purity, precept-holding, single-minded devotion, reverence, and unwavering respect. Without thought of merit or intent to impress, one acts without ulterior motive, utterly free from pretense or interruption. This is what Confucius meant by "even in haste or during a meal, never deviating," and what the *Doctrine of the Mean* describes as "finding fulfillment in every circumstance." Zhuangzi expounded the essence of *carefree wandering*, Hai Chan composed the *Song of Joy*, Buddhism speaks of *great freedom*, and the Confucian classics speak of *daily renewal*—all are natural effects. How could they be borrowed or forced?

Alas! Purity and right faith, even without relying on ritual codes or performing fasts and jiao offerings, possess this natural merit. Thus, the profound teachings of the Dao lie in truly embodying the scriptures' meaning. Ritual codes and jiao offerings merely propagate the Dharma to spread the Dao’s transformation. Chen Tuan chanted the *Scripture of Salvation* and attained the Dao—this was truly upholding the scripture’s essence. Today’s jiao offerings lack evident efficacy because they possess grand rituals but no true cultivation. If purity and right faith are combined with jiao offerings, their merit is greatly enhanced. Without jiao offerings, true sincerity alone still yields divine merit. But without true sincerity, jiao offerings become mere formalities—how could they avoid fault?

**Chapter Eight: Protection and Upholding**

At that time, the August Heavenly Thearch, having spoken these verses, addressed the great assembly, saying: These are the wondrous dharma-words of the Jade Emperor, the secret and arcane utterances of all the sages. The path is severed, the Dao cut off—subtle and profound beyond thought, majestic and vast in scope, the foundation of all divine luminaries. It safeguards and stabilizes the realm, delivering beings from birth and death.

When the August Heavenly Thearch had finished speaking these words, the pure assembly of the dharma gathering all gazed upward toward the Dao’s discourse, universally attaining enlightenment.

At that time, the August Heavenly Thearch bowed in reverence and extolled the Jade Emperor. Having recited the verses, he addressed the assembled host of celestial immortals, perfected beings, divine generals, and all others, saying: These are the wondrous dharma-words of the Jade Emperor.

All the immortal sages possess their own dharma-words—vast yet measurable, transmitted within limits. Some may know their beginning and end; some benefit the living but neglect the dead; some aid humans but forsake other beings; some are recognized by ghosts and spirits, while others fail to subdue demons and malevolent forces. Some remain formless and unknowing, unable to universally deliver—none are wondrous or sublime.

Yet the transformative power of this scripture is infinite, its majesty and benefit immeasurable. All receive its blessings—it is no ordinary teaching. These are the wondrous dharma-words of the Jade Emperor, the secret and arcane utterances of all the perfected sages.

When the Primordial Beginning expounded this scripture, how could it be said that all the sages and most perfected ones who heard and received it did not treasure it, daring not to lightly disclose it? Thus it is called the "secret of all the sages," the "arcane words." The path is severed, the Dao cut off—this is the supreme vehicle. The dharma is rarely heard, the essential path of cultivating the real, the circuit of entering sagehood. Illusory desires and false thoughts—here, their roots are plucked. Love, attachments, and mundane thoughts—no longer sprout or spread. The cycles of rebirth and transmigration—severed in one stroke. Thus it is said: the path is severed, the Dao cut off. Another version states: the Seven Sages are all deluded, and this is a path humans find difficult to tread—this is also true.

Subtle and profound beyond thought—deep, mysterious, and wondrous. The divine cannot be grasped by thought, nor entered through contemplation. The human mind’s reflections cannot easily reach it. Majestic and towering, the wondrous model of immortal verses, the true seal of the divine luminaries’ hearts. Another interpretation: the Jade Emperor’s Dao is the model, the ancestral teacher of all divine luminaries. This is too restrictive.

It safeguards and stabilizes the realm, delivering beings from birth and death.

At that time, the August Heavenly Thearch, having spoken these wondrous dharma-words up to the phrase "delivering from birth and death,"—the dharma gathering, the flower-adorned assembly; the pure assembly, the assembly of pure and sacred beings—all gazed upward toward the Dao’s discourse. Or, some take it as gazing upward toward the wondrous dharma-words of the August Heavenly Thearch. Universally attaining enlightenment, all achieved awakening.

**Verification:**
The Master’s words on human nature and the Dao of Heaven cannot be heard. The *Wenshi Jing* states: "Sages and the wise create delusion; even ghosts and spirits do not comprehend." When the Buddha expounded the dharma on Vulture Peak, the bodhisattvas listened with rapt attention. The Jade Emperor’s dharma-words—severed path, cut-off Dao, subtle and profound beyond thought—what doubt can there be? As the foundation of all divine luminaries, stabilizing the realm and delivering beings from birth and death—these are its natural effects.

**Resolving Doubts:**
There are no people beyond the Dao in the world, nor is there a Dao beyond people. Humans, beings, the hidden and the manifest—all are the Dao. Human nature is wholly real; all things are complete within it. All transformations and nurturing, the world’s beginning and end—all are the reality of our nature. The Jade Emperor is the embodiment of the Dao; the scripture is the Dao’s intent. Only the Dao achieves complete spiritual transformation, its wondrous essence naturally so. Humans share the same nature—how could they not uphold this scripture? Knowing the Dao resides within, embodying the Dao with a single heart, generation after generation without duality—then the perfected sages are within me.

At that time, the Most High Heavenly Worthy of Primordial Beginning addressed the Four Perfected Ones—Compassionate Deliverance from Suffering and the others—saying: "Among all the beings of the world—those who are stubborn, violent, and fierce, whose nature is bold and conduct coarse, the unvirtuous, whose words and deeds are wicked—who spend their days and nights (here, *jing* means ‘end,’ ‘exhaust’; they exhaust day and exhaust night) before the images of the Dao and the sacred likenesses of the gods, yet harbor no reverence in their hearts and utter slanderous words (*fei*: to criticize with words; *bang*: to defame with words), thus showing disrespect to the images of the Dao and slandering the sacred—such sins condemn them to the Five Uninterrupted Hells, the great hells of the netherworld. Without the methods of the sage, they inevitably fall into this retribution. Observe the laws of the world that punish those who slander heretical teachings, and you will understand the gravity of slandering the gods.

"If they encounter one who upholds this scripture (here, *zhi yu* means that at that time, they happen to meet), who employs various expedient methods of salvation to guide and instruct them—those who slander the gods and revile the Dharma, whose karmic roots are deep and heavy, who are obstinately deluded and lack faith—the upholder of the scripture, with great compassion and expedient means, awakens, guides, and transforms them, revealing their innate goodness and arousing their virtuous thoughts. Thus, those who slander the gods and revile the Dharma may extinguish all their evil minds, believe in and turn toward this scripture, take refuge with sincere faith, and devote themselves to it. Their karmic offenses (here, *bi* refers to those who slander the gods and revile the Dharma) will be entirely purified without remainder. As their karma dissolves and their sins vanish, all retribution is exhausted, and they are forever freed from transgression, never to return. Constantly pure and clean, their evil retribution is permanently removed, and no unresolved karma remains. Even in the Uninterrupted Hell, where karma is difficult to dissolve, if one wholeheartedly believes in and turns toward the true scripture, evil roots are severed at once, all defilements are extinguished, and what fetters remain? With roots and defilements instantly eradicated, karma is purified without remainder.

The virtue of the gods and the merit of the scriptures bring the greatest benefit. Both teachings emphatically speak of sin and blessing, earnestly revealing the gravity of the sin of disrespecting the gods and slandering the Dharma. Confucians likewise warn against flattery and irreverence toward the spirits—how could Confucians fail to revere the gods or honor the scriptures? The *Book of Songs* says: *"Do not disgrace those who gave you life."* Master Zhang said: *"To feel no shame in the solitude of one’s chamber is to not disgrace one’s origins."* He also said: *"To preserve the mind and nurture one’s nature is to be unwavering."* Both teachings speak of revering the gods and honoring the scriptures to cultivate the mind and practice the Dao, feeling no shame before heaven, earth, and the gods, believing in the words of the Dharma, and embodying the Dao to attain the real.

Confucians speak of not flattering the gods to caution against seeking blessings through irreverence. Serving Heaven, revering Heaven, aspiring to Heaven, honoring the words of the former kings, responding with reverent haste—Confucianism and the two teachings are one in this. If sacrifices bring no benefit and reverence is not practiced, if the Mandate of Heaven is not feared, these are corrupt words. Confucians also sternly reprove such views—how could this apply only to the two teachings?

Alas! Good and evil, reverence and negligence—all arise from the mind. If one severs desire, relinquishes cunning knowledge, empties the five aggregates, and removes the five burdens, then one is no longer bound by the five phases. Heaven and earth cannot restrain them, so how could the Five Uninterrupted Hells ensnare them? The Buddha said: *"By reciting the Buddha’s name, fire pits transform into lotus ponds."* Mencius said: *"Recite the words of Yao and practice the deeds of Yao, and you are Yao."* Thus, the true efficacy of goodness is immediately manifest.

**Chapter on Verification, Continuation of Chapter Thirteen**

Moreover, if there are wicked and foolish men of perverse views and obstinate delusion who, upon seeing one upholding this scripture, give rise to all manner of evil and rebellion—casting sidelong, crooked glances, or even harboring a single malicious thought, uttering a single wicked word, and recklessly slandering those who uphold the scripture—their transgression is profoundly grave. After the end of their lives, they shall fall into the great hells, with no hope of escape.

Not only is the sin of disrespecting the gods and slandering the scripture severe. Again, if there are foolish and benighted men of perverse views and obstinate delusion who, upon beholding those who recite and uphold this scripture—*beholding* meaning to see with their own eyes—give rise to all manner of evil and rebellion, lacking faith in their hearts, failing to recognize that the scripture contains the words of the Dao and the teachings of the Dharma, and that upholding it brings benefit, they grow arrogant and dismissive, despising and slandering it. They give rise to all manner of transgressions and rebellious acts, casting sidelong, crooked glances, unwilling to see the scripture or those who uphold it. They lack the proper gaze of settled observation, instead casting biased, perverse glances, treating them with contempt, aversion, and disdain. Even if they harbor a single malicious thought or utter a single wicked word, recklessly slandering those who uphold the scripture—*slander* meaning to praise or defame—their offense is grave. Upholding the scripture is a virtuous act and must not be defamed. Yet these wicked and obstinate men, ignorant of karmic causes, sins, and blessings, unaware of the goodness of upholding the scripture, recklessly generate slanderous, abusive, and reviling speech against those who uphold it. Their transgression is profoundly grave. After the end of their lives—*end* meaning their allotted span is exhausted.

They fall into the great hells, the Avīci Hell, with no end to their confinement. *Permanent* means final, eternal. Those who recklessly slander the true Dharma plant deep karmic roots, and thus their fall into hell makes escape nearly impossible.

All perception is one. If perception is not upright, it becomes perverse. All people are one; if they cling to delusion and fail to awaken, they become foolish and wicked. The heart is one; if it generates evil thoughts, it becomes rebellious. The eyes are one; if they cast biased, perverse glances, they become transgressive. A single thought, however minute, is one; if it gives rise to an evil intention, it becomes the root of karma. A single word, however slight, is one; if it utters an evil speech, it becomes the source of sin.

The noble person perfects the beauty of unity, commending others’ goodness. Those who uphold the scripture should be praised; to recklessly generate slander is to create one’s own suffering. Human life is originally free of karma, yet one invites grave sin upon oneself—how deeply lamentable.

The end of life is the return of the borrowed vessel of creation, naturally unbound. Yet for one who slanders the Dharma, even death brings no peace. How endless is their suffering, with no hope of escape.

The heart of Heaven is benevolent; the Supreme Deity cherishes life. The spirits are upright and do not abandon people. Yet if the sinner has no end to their confinement, is it Heaven that restrains them? No—calamity is self-made, and fixed karma is inescapable.

To dissolve one’s own karma, one must return to self-faith. Unwavering devotion to supreme goodness severs the root of karma. Alas! Heaven’s punishment is impartial; the law has no favorites. A compassionate father cannot shield his son, nor can a filial son protect his father. The spirits are perfectly just—how could they absolve self-inflicted karma?

Those who believe in the scripture and turn toward the Dharma may repent of past transgressions, just as a worldly person who confesses sincerely may be spared punishment. In this world, the sagely and the foolish are not inherently different. If one cannot speak with eloquence, let their voice at least follow the rhythm of the law; if one cannot avoid uttering false words, let them at least refrain from evil speech. If one cannot act without fault, let their body at least serve as a vessel for liberation; if one cannot avoid wrongdoing, let them at least refrain from creating bodily karma. If one cannot guard against delusive thoughts, let them at least preserve their utmost sincerity; if one cannot avoid evil intentions, let them at least refrain from creating mental karma.

If one does not understand the great Dao, let them not slander it. If one cannot comprehend the scripture, let them not reject it. If one cannot recite or uphold it, let them not slander others. If one does not understand spirits, life and death, or cause and effect, let them not utter defamatory words. With a heart of upright faith, clarity in the Dao will naturally arise over time, gradually attaining sagehood and transcendence—what karma or sin could then remain?

**Chapter Fourteen: Verification of Retribution Continued**

As for men and women in the world who encounter this scripture yet fail to revere it, handling it with filthy hands, reciting it with impure mouths, or placing it upon unclean beds and couches—those who, while reciting or expounding it, engage in vulgar speech and frivolous laughter, treating it as an ordinary text—such people, after their lives end, will fall into the Avīci Hell with no hope of escape. Their misfortune will extend to nine generations of ancestors, who will suffer interrogation in Fengdu. Their sins will burden their descendants, afflicting future generations.

In hell, they will endure immeasurable kalpas of immense suffering. Even if they encounter the sacred teachings and receive repeated salvation, their sins will only slightly diminish. If they further receive the extraordinary mercy of the highest sages, they may escape hell, only to be reborn among the hungry ghosts. For thousands of myriads of kalpas, they will not even hear the name of water or broth. Once their ghostly retribution is exhausted, they will be reborn as animals. After their animal retribution is complete, if they are reborn as humans, they will again appear in remote barbarian lands, as women, in poverty and hardship, afflicted with chronic illnesses and disabilities, enduring boundless suffering. They will be despised and rejected by all, unable to live in peace or die in ease. Such is the gravity of the sin incurred by treating this scripture lightly.

This is the retribution for disrespecting the scripture. *Failing to revere* means lacking respect and admiration. *Handling with filthy hands* refers to touching or flipping through the scripture with unclean hands, thereby defiling it. *Reciting with an impure mouth* means chanting or upholding it after consuming the five pungent vegetables, the five spices, or the three tabooed meats. *Placing it upon unclean beds or couches* means setting the scripture on dirty tables, seats, or platforms. *Engaging in vulgar speech and frivolous laughter* means discussing it in common language and treating it as a trivial text.

Such people not only bring sin upon themselves but also extend calamity to nine generations of ancestors—the four paternal uncles, the four maternal uncles, and the first ancestor. *Suffering interrogation in Fengdu* refers to the examination of transgressions, or the torture of interrogation. This reflects the principle that when a minor ghost commits a crime, the household head is held accountable. *Burdening descendants* means that the sins of an unvirtuous family linger, bringing endless suffering and affliction.

If they encounter the sacred teachings and receive repeated salvation, their sins may slightly diminish—this is the merit of the scripture and the Dharma. If they receive the extraordinary mercy of the highest sages, it is the pardon of the Supreme Deity, allowing them to escape the suffering of hell. Yet as hungry ghosts, they will endure thousands of myriads of kalpas without even hearing the name of water or broth. Hungry ghosts have vast bellies and narrow throats, making it impossible to consume food or drink. In the dark hells of Fengdu, they neither see nor hear of water or broth.

There is no creature more foolish than animals. Once their ghostly retribution is exhausted, they are reborn among them, their karma still unresolved. Though human existence is one, rebirth in the Central Kingdom is rare, and obtaining a male body is difficult. They will be born in remote barbarian lands, as women—among the least favored of human forms—enduring poverty, cold, hunger, and hardship, afflicted with chronic illnesses and disabilities, suffering boundless torment. They will be despised and rejected, unable to live in peace or die in ease—all due to their disrespect for this scripture. The gravity of their sin is truly lamentable.

Human life is one of the Three Powers, alongside Heaven and Earth. This body is precious, entrusted to us to continue our lineage, honor our ancestors, and benefit descendants. The Dao depends on it for transmission—its significance is not trivial. To slight the scripture and the Dharma brings calamity upon oneself, extends misfortune to ancestors, and burdens descendants with karmic retribution. How profoundly foolish is such a person?

Moreover, examining the texts of the Three Teachings, they declare that in the nature of the Dharma, there is no distinction between male and female—everywhere and in every place is a land of bliss. As the *Doctrine of the Mean* states: "In wealth or poverty, in high station or low, among barbarians or in times of peril, act according to one’s lot and find contentment in all circumstances." Yet why is it said that those in foreign lands as women, or those afflicted with illness and hardship, are despised and rejected by others?

The absence of distinction, where all find contentment, is the Dao. The differentiation of ranks and the discourse on sin and blessing are the workings of karmic retribution. When retribution is made clear, people are thus moved to goodness. Alas! All humans are one—all may become good people. Strive diligently to advance in the Dao, refrain from creating karma, and avoid being despised by others.

The benefits of this scriptural Dharma are not such that only the utterly faithless incur sin. The Youths of Good and Evil—those who record the good and evil deeds of the world—report to the Three Officials, inscribing their names in the Black Register (the ledger of transgressions) for the sin of disdaining the scripture. Some are imprisoned in fetters, or meet untimely deaths by their own hands. Some are harmed by poison, or devoured and mauled by tigers, wolves, or venomous serpents. Some are seized by creditors and subjected to harm. Some, while traveling through mountains and forests, encounter brigands who murder them, dismember them, or cast them from cliffs, wounding their bodies and ending their lives. Some are secretly harmed by malevolent spirits and spectral beings. Some perish in fires or are swept away by floods. Some are slain by the sword in war. For the sin of disdaining this scripture, they suffer untimely deaths, cut short in their prime, denied a peaceful end. Such are the karmic consequences, such is the retribution—how can this not be lamentable? How can it not be agonizing?

Grieving their suffering, we also mourn their folly—this is the great compassion of the Heavenly Worthy.

**Resolving Doubts:**
If even a single act of disdain for this scripture incurs boundless retribution, then revering the Dao and believing in the scripture must be a matter of constancy. Through long cultivation, the transformative power of the Dao is perfected, and the efficacy of the scripture is fully realized, bestowing its virtue and manifesting its effects. Yet people, lacking steadfastness, begin with diligence but end in indolence—no wonder sin and karma befall them.

From ancient times to the present, those of inferior capacity abound—many neither uphold nor even hear the scripture, yet suffer misfortunes and calamities. Are they all guilty of disdaining the scripture? The scripture speaks of the Dao; to disbelieve in the Dao is to lack virtue, which is itself the sin of disdaining the scripture. Without virtue, there is sin—this is the sin of disdaining the scripture. To revere the scripture and dissolve sin, one must advance in the Dao and cultivate virtue.

The effects of the *Treasure Sutra of Heavenly Beings* may thus be known to the world. Take heed.

Those who contemplate this scripture, take heed—supreme merit and power await. **Verifications, Chapter Nineteen**

Without having planted the roots of the Dao in past lives or widely sown the fields of blessings, one may not even hear the scripture’s name, let alone behold its text. The merits of this scripture are indeed inexhaustible.

If one has not planted the roots of the Dao—*roots* being the foundation—then, as the noble person attends to the root, once the root is established, the Dao arises. Hence, it is called the *root of the Dao*. (One version mistakenly writes *seed of the Dao*.) *Su* means "long-standing" or "preparatory"; *zhi* means "to establish," "to plant," or "to sow." The *root of the Dao* refers to the gradual progression of cultivation, the foundation for entering the Dao. The *Daoist Scriptures* state: "The Great Dao has no name." Through refined cultivation, it is perfected. Confucius said: "Study the lower to reach the higher." The Buddhist scriptures say: "Through hearing, reflection, and cultivation, one enters samādhi." All three teachings esteem learning as the foundation for attaining the Dao.

Yet though the Dao may be suddenly realized, it must be gradually cultivated—truly, it cannot be mastered in a single step. Without prior practice in past or present lives, without first planting the roots of the Dao and widely sowing the fields of blessings—*fields of blessings* being where merit accumulates with effect, like sowing a field—then:

**External deeds** include repairing palaces, temples, hermitages, ancestral halls, shrines, pagodas, pavilions, communal halls, bridges, roads; administering medicine and treating illness; aiding the state and saving people; issuing talismans and performing rituals; praying for offspring; benefiting beings; dispelling evil; averting calamity; relieving suffering; and rescuing the poor.

**Internal practices** include compassion, joyful giving, forbearance, harmonious radiance, universal and impartial generosity, and steadfast perfection.

**Coarse actions** include donating wealth, clothing, and food.

**Secret practices** include contemplating the Dao and meditating on the True, cutting off desire to nurture spirit, accumulating essence and storing qi.

To ascend to sagehood and transcend the mundane—such methods are manifold. The boundless fields of blessings must all be widely sown.

Those who cultivate worldly fields may face droughts, floods, or human mismanagement, resulting in poor harvests. But those who cultivate the fields of blessings—whether in small or great measure—shall reap small or great rewards. The hidden virtues are manifold; even if one remains unaware or their enumeration is inexhaustible, their merit is boundless. Should one fail to cultivate these fields of blessings, they may not even hear the name of this scripture. Without virtue or fortune, the scripture’s name remains unheard.

As the scripture states, the true Dharma is rarely encountered—this is what it means. How much more so to behold this scripture itself? To see this true scripture is to possess the Dao-eye. Without virtue or fortune, its name goes unheard; how then could one hope to see it?

Each person’s capacity differs, as does their reception. Some possess fortune but lack virtue—wealthy and noble yet foolish. Others possess virtue but lack fortune—poor yet sagely. When virtue and fortune flourish together, one attains rank, longevity, and renown. Should one encounter the true Dharma and gain insight into liberation, it is not through mere kalpas of cultivation or boundless merit that such a state is reached.

At a gathering of a million buddhas, the true Dharma was entrusted to Mahākāśyapa. Among Confucius’ three thousand disciples, the unifying principle was passed to Zeng Shen. In the Daoist tradition, though its followers number in the millions, only Wenshi inherited the heart of the Most High.

Let the reader take heed.

**Chapter Twenty: Verification**

This scripture adheres to the true standards of the Three Caverns. It is transmitted but once in eighty thousand kalpas—a treasure cherished by the perfected sages of the Pure Capital, secreted within the Golden Towers of the Jade Capital. Most wondrous and subtle, it is rarely encountered. Only those with the bone of immortality—destined to become true immortals of the Nine Heavens—may chance upon this text. Having met with this opportunity, they shall later present gold and treasures to their master, swear oaths, and receive it. Only then, when the time is ripe and fate aligns, may it be transmitted. It must not be lightly disclosed; revere it, guard it well. This scripture is not to be casually passed on.

It adheres to the true standards of the Three Caverns: the Cavern of Truth, the Cavern of Mystery, and the Cavern of Spirit—these three ranks are recorded in the celestial statutes and golden precepts. The "true standards" are the natural principles. "Eighty thousand kalpas" refers to the cycles of cosmic renewal spanning eighty thousand great kalpas. One tradition holds that human life begins at *yin* and ends at *you*, with eight periods totaling 86,400 years—roughly eighty thousand years. Each cycle of growth, harvest, and renewal is called a kalpa. "Sand" signifies innumerable grains. The transmission of this scripture once in eighty thousand kalpas marks the turning of the great Dharma-wheel—an exceedingly rare occurrence. The earlier explanation is nearly correct.

This is a treasure of the perfected sages of the Pure Capital of Supreme Clarity, secreted within the Golden Towers of the Jade Capital—not the abode of the Jade Emperor, but the repository of the *Tai Xuan Bao Zang Di Jing*. Most wondrous and subtle, its praises extol the difficulty of encountering it. Only those with the bone of immortality—those who have cultivated in past lives and possess the destiny of transcendence—may become true immortals of the Nine Heavens. Having met with this text and this karmic connection, they shall later present gold and treasures to their master, swear oaths, and receive it. This is not merely the offering of worldly gold and treasures, but the pledge of a heart utterly sincere and selfless, unwavering for all kalpas—a vow sworn before heaven and earth, as pure as the midday sun, untarnished by even a speck of dust. Such is true, indestructible gold.

Only then, when the moment arrives and fate aligns, may it be transmitted. It must not be lightly disclosed. To "disclose" is to leak; the scripture’s essence must not be carelessly revealed, nor shared with the unworthy. Revere it, guard it well. Alas! Knowing the weight of this scripture, all should cultivate good karma as the foundation for receiving it. Once received, it must never be treated lightly. Treasure it, strive for it.

*Were the waters of rivers and streams*
*To bear lotuses in their waves...*

The rivers run deep, their currents vast and waves towering—yet they cannot bear lotuses. The feathers of kind crows are naturally black—yet they cannot turn white. To speak of white crows or lotus-bearing rivers is to describe the impossible, and thus to illustrate the extreme rarity of encountering this scripture.

Turtles are naturally without fur, and the moon is inherently the Great Yin. To speak of gathering turtle fur for clothing or melting ice with the night moon is but to describe the utterly nonexistent—thus illustrating the extreme rarity of encountering this scripture. Moreover, to say that the legs of mosquitoes and midges could construct bridges to bear heavy loads; that fledglings with yellow beaks could carry great mountains and cast them into other realms; that a small boat could ferry Mount Kunlun across the vast sea; or that leeches could grow the tusks of elephants—leeches being but tiny water insects—these too are impossibilities. Or that the leaves of mugwort and reeds could cover boundless worlds and shade Mount Kunlun; that crows and owls, both ill-omened birds, could nest together and feed one another in filial reciprocity; that rabbit horns could serve as ladders to ascend to heaven; that a shrew could climb such a ladder to reach the heavens and devour the moon; that donkeys’ lips could turn the hue of *pingpo* fruit and sing and dance; or that flies and insects could drink barrels of wine and grow drunk and lost—all these are things that must never exist, principles that have never been. Yet they are recounted in detail to show how difficult it is to encounter this scripture.

The Great Dao is possessed by all, and the true scripture is complete in each. Even the foolish and the dull-witted have their correct nature and may all be transformed and delivered—why then compare the rarity of this scripture to such impossibilities? Could it truly never be transmitted? The answer lies in the hierarchy of teachings: this scripture is the most exalted. Those who transmit it may not embody the truth of the Primordial Beginning, and those who receive it may not grasp the secrets of the Jade Emperor. With obstructions and biases, the full scripture remains obscure. Some may never hear or see it; others may hear or see it in vain, their understanding of its merit and efficacy left vague. Without attaining its full benefit, one must indeed acknowledge its rarity.

Yet the difficulty of difficulty need not be feared. With utmost sincerity and reverence, the merit of the scripture will naturally be met.

They are called a *Body of Spiritual Penetration*. Though humans are the most spiritually endowed, they possess no spiritual penetration. The wondrous Dharma within this scripture is supremely profound and divine, unobstructedly transcendent—thus the upholder of this true scripture is called a *Body of Spiritual Penetration*. All auspicious signs gather in their presence. The sages of the Three Teachings are eternally perfected and indestructible. *Xian* means "all"; *zhen* means "to arrive"; *ji* means "to assemble." The blessings they attain are manifold, with a thousand auspicious signs converging. Heaven does not withhold the Dao; Earth does not hoard its treasures. People submit to their transformation; things respond to their numinous power—all auspicious signs gather in their presence.

They are called a *Body of Purity*. That which is unstained is *pure*; that which is unburdened is *clear*. The upholder of the scripture quiets all entanglements, leaving not a single flaw—thus no evil can assail them. *Qin* means "to encroach and harm." Whether self-inflicted karma, heavenly calamities, past transgressions, or present faults; whether the misfortunes of ancestors or the obstructions of the times; whether the afflictions of fate, the clashes of stellar positions, the assaults of demons and ghosts, the slander of people, or the malevolence of things—all such evil karma is transformed from inauspicious to auspicious, unable to encroach or harm. The person of the Dao encompasses Heaven and Earth, nurturing all beings. Their blessings and felicity are everlasting, and Heaven’s protection never wanes. The virtuous are aided by Heaven, free from disaster and harm—truly a *Body of Merit, Spiritual Penetration, and Purity*. Those who merely possess a body but lack merit, spiritual penetration, and purity do not truly uphold the scripture. Strive on, and one may verify its efficacy for oneself.

**Resolving Doubts:**
The Confucians say: *"Be cautious in what you do not see, fearful in what you do not hear."* Is not caution and fear itself a kind of dread? Moreover, the seven emotions—joy, anger, sorrow, thought, grief, terror, and shock—reside in every person. Yet it is said that wherever one goes, he knows no fear—does this not contradict caution and fear?

It is not so. Caution and fear restrain human desire to preserve the true Dao. The seven emotions demonstrate the full functioning of human nature, guiding people to subdue their passions and return to their nature. But if the heart of dread arises from inner instability, giving rise to external calamity, and one is seized by terror, this is not the proper way. Thus, the Master said: *"Look within and find no fault—what worry, what fear?"* Wherever he goes, he knows no fear, for body and Dao are one, and all he encounters is peace. What fear could there be?

The Confucians also say: *"Seeing the great, the heart is at peace."* This and the above illuminate each other. For one who upholds the scripture, fearlessness in coming and going is natural—not forced.

Forced restraint, like Gaozi’s "unmoving heart," ultimately fails to perceive the Dao. Spontaneity, however—Confucius’s freedom from doubt and following the heart, Mencius’s "unmoving heart"—all align with the meaning of this scripture. How excellent are the teachings of both traditions on the study of the heart: *"Thusness, naturalness, majestic immovability"*—the way of spiritual transformation is fully contained therein. If one clings through effort, no spontaneous transformation occurs, and the practice cannot endure. Seeking quick results, even without fear, still does not accord with the scripture’s meaning.

Here, the Jade Emperor is the Teacher of all Heavens—the thirty-three heavens, thirty-six heavens, twelve thousand heavens, and the three thousand great worlds—all who realize the great Dao through the *August Scripture*. The Jade Emperor is the Teacher of all Heavens, the transformer who perfects the hosts of perfected beings. He is the King of all Sages, for all immortals, Confucian sages, buddhas, gods of the heavens, and all holy beings yield to his virtue, defer to his merits, and acknowledge his supremacy, revering him through endless kalpas. Alas, when the Heavenly Lord within a person is at peace, the Dao may be attained. If one does not cultivate the heart to awaken and unite virtue with Heaven, vainly revering the Supreme Emperor, it is a grievous error. Beware and reflect on this.

**Chapter Thirty-Three of the Verification Section Continued**
Therefore, when an ordinary person encounters this scripture and cultivates it with single-minded devotion, they may even command the Five Emperors as their assistants, summon and employ the hosts of immortals, direct and govern the spirit officials, and guide the workings of yin and yang. A thousand spirits will revere them, ten thousand gods will submit in awe, all evil will avoid their path, and the myriad demons will constrain their forms. After the end of their life, they will immediately undergo refinement in the Southern Palace, ascend to the Upper Clarity, and roam freely and at ease, abiding with the Dao forever. It is not only the Golden Immortals and great worthies who realize the Dao through this scripture. Therefore, when an ordinary person encounters this scripture—an ordinary being of the world who, by karmic conditions, meets this scripture and cultivates it with single-minded devotion—even the Five Emperors (the Five Elder Sovereigns, not the Five Sacred Peaks) will assist their progress and support their shortcomings. They may summon and employ the hosts of immortals, directing and commanding the spirit officials. *Summon and employ* means to issue commands, and the immortals will obey; *direct and command* means to control and dispatch, and the spirit officials will serve. As the scripture says: "Those who cultivate the Dao may command ghosts and drive away spirits." Though an ordinary person, through single-minded devotion to the scripture, the power of the Dao subdues them, enabling them to summon immortals and command spirits, guiding the workings of yin and yang. Only with utmost sincerity and singular focus, faithfully upholding this scripture, can one naturally govern creation, harmonizing yin and yang. A thousand spirits will revere them, a thousand spirits will honor and look up to them. Ten thousand gods will submit in awe—*submit* meaning to be struck with reverent fear and obedience; *awe* meaning to restrain their spirits and submit silently. The ten thousand gods submit without need for coercion. All evil will avoid their path, and the myriad demons will constrain their forms, daring not to appear.

Upon the end of one’s allotted span, the liberation shall be as foretold. They shall attain refinement in the Southern Palace—the Southern Palace being the Vermilion Mound Prefecture, the palace for refining and delivering souls. *Refinement* here denotes the process of being tempered and delivered in the Southern Palace. They shall ascend to the Upper Clarity by flying steps, their spirit soaring to the celestial realms of Upper Clarity—though this is not the true Upper Clarity realm, but merely an expression of ascension to heaven. They shall roam freely and at ease, spared the trials of hell, exempt from karmic retribution, unbound and unshackled, carefree and unfettered. They shall abide with the Dao in perpetuity. From the moment they first uphold this scripture, though not yet perfected, through single-minded devotion and reverent practice, their heart resonates with the Dao, unobstructed and untethered. Their hun-soul and spirit purified, they shall no longer suffer dissolution or descent, but endure with the Dao forever. This is what the Daoist canon means by "death yet not perishing," and what the Buddhist scriptures call "awakening and thus liberation." If even an ordinary person, through single-minded devotion to this scripture, may attain such efficacy, then the power of utmost sincerity is evident. Though of humble intellect, one may yet fulfill the Dao—let the reader take heed.

**Chapter Thirty-Four: Manifest Verifications**

Moreover, when sentient beings in the world hear this scripture and their hearts arise in longing and reverence, they may choose a pure and secluded place within their homes to enshrine the image of the August Lord. Day and night, they shall offer devout worship, morning incense rising in abundance, with fragrant flowers, lamps, fruits, and solemn offerings. They shall honor and venerate, chant the sacred names, gaze in reverence, and recite the scripture. Such a person shall attain thirty sublime virtues:

First, the praise and esteem of all immortals;
Second, the rebirth of departed ancestors in heaven;
Third, the dissolution of past misfortunes;
Fourth, unimpeded passage wherever they go;

**Fifth,** freedom from theft and banditry;
**Sixth,** the fulfillment of all desires;
**Seventh,** deliverance from water and fire calamities;
**Eighth,** the silent dissolution of misfortunes;
**Ninth,** auspicious dreams at night;
**Tenth,** immunity from illness;
**Eleventh,** wisdom and keen intelligence;
**Twelfth,** delight in the sight of others;
**Thirteenth,** abundance in clothing and food;
**Fourteenth,** honor and nobility for descendants—let them be virtuous and pure, free from baseness, ignominy, or early death, and all shall be well;
**Fifteenth,** joy among the six relations;
**Sixteenth,** harmony within the clan;
**Seventeenth,** eradication of the three evil retributions;
**Eighteenth,** transformation of a woman’s body into a man’s;
**Nineteenth,** a dignified and majestic appearance;
**Twentieth,** appointment as a great minister of the state;
**Twenty-first,** birth as the son of an emperor;
**Twenty-second,** reverence and admiration from ghosts and spirits;
**Twenty-third,** attainment of knowledge of past lives—all karmic obstructions dissolved, and life’s path made smooth;
**Twenty-fourth,** protection and mindfulness from all deities;
**Twenty-fifth,** the nine clans receiving blessings—the nine clans being: high ancestors, great-grandparents, grandparents, parents, oneself, children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and great-great-grandchildren; or, alternatively, three clans on the father’s side, three on the mother’s, and three on the wife’s;
**Twenty-sixth,** longevity in the world;
**Twenty-seventh,** all sentient beings relying on one’s virtuous merit;
**Twenty-eighth,** the demon kings safeguarding and welcoming;
**Twenty-ninth,** transcending the three realms of desire, form, and formlessness in succession;
**Thirtieth,** ascension in broad daylight.

Though immortals ascend in varied ways—not all necessarily rising bodily in daylight—those who attain this state become as vast as the great void, their spirits roaming the Jade Capital: this is ascension in broad daylight.

Devout reverence for this scripture and the August Lord yields such merits, yet one must first utterly renounce secret desires, seek no verification of effects, and persist without interruption. When the heart aligns with heaven, efficacy follows; even if it does not, no harm comes from doing good. Should one covet verification, they have not truly transmitted the scripture of the August Lord. Let the reader take heed.

**Chapter Thirty-Five: Further Manifest Verifications**

Then the Heavenly Worthy addressed the four assemblies, saying: The merits of this scripture can shatter the Iron Enclosure and all mountains, drain the waters of the Sea of Suffering, break open the great hells, and liberate all from sin and suffering. It subdues violent demons, protects all lands, annihilates all evil spirits, cures all grave illnesses, dissolves all poisons, severs ties with all wicked people, tames all venomous beasts, and overthrows all heterodox paths. All the heavens revere it, and its remaining merits are beyond enumeration.

Devout reverence for this scripture and the August Lord yields thirty kinds of merit.

Then the Heavenly Worthy again addressed the four assemblies, saying: The merits of this scripture can crush the Yin Feng and Iron Enclosure mountains, purifying all past defilements. It dries the waves of the Sea of Suffering, allowing one to turn back and ascend its shores. It shatters the great hells, stilling delusive conditions. It uproots all sin and suffering, severing karmic roots to forever end retribution. It subdues violent demons, restraining their fierce and malevolent perversity. It protects all lands, bringing purity and peace, enriching nations and securing the people. It annihilates all evil spirits, eradicating the dark and malevolent. It cures all grave illnesses, eliminating all defilements. It dissolves all poisons, dispelling worldly toxins and the great inner poisons of the body. It severs ties with all wicked people—either preventing encounters or causing them to flee at one’s sight. It tames all venomous beasts, pacifying the world’s poisonous creatures.

Moreover, those who cultivate the Dao—through the transformation of yin qi—command countless dragons, fierce beasts, giant serpents, and lions, each in the hundreds of millions, to guard this true scripture, rendering them docile and eternally protective.

It shatters all heterodox ways, crushing the world’s myriad deviant paths and demolishing one’s own deluded attachments. All the heavens—every realm’s celestial beings—naturally revere and honor this scripture. Its remaining virtues are beyond enumeration; as previously described, the merits of this scripture dissolve calamities and their transformations, eradicate disasters and their poisons, transform all without exception, and benefit all without limit. It is the great expedient, the supreme dharma among all teachings. Though uttered in the subtle words of the utmost sagely, it is the very function of one’s inherent nature. Strive diligently, and merit will naturally manifest.

**Chapter on Manifest Verification, Continuation of the Thirty-Sixth**

At that time, the assembly in the Dao altar—Golden Immortals, Bodhisattvas, and the retinue of Perfected Sages—having heard this teaching, rejoiced with exultation. They bowed their heads in reverence and offered this hymn of praise:

Great is the supreme Dao,
Peerless, the Most High Perfected.
Above, it delivers the heavens;
Below, it rescues the lost souls.
Without master or ancestor,
The Dao alone is its body.
Cinnabar Terrace and Purple Palace,
Golden Gates and Jade Capital—
Here is concealed this wondrous dharma,
Bestowing blessings upon all beings,
Erasing my ten thousand sins,
Prolonging my distant years.
Myriad spirits pay homage,
Demon kings guard and welcome.
Virtues flourish and prosper,
My name inscribed in the Yellow Register.
Through boundless eons,
May I endure forever.

When the assembly had finished reciting this hymn, they bowed their heads in homage, took their leave, and departed.

At that time, the assembly in the Dao altar—the place where the Dao is expounded—Golden Immortals, Bodhisattvas, and the retinue of Perfected Sages, having heard the scripture’s conclusion, rejoiced with exultation, their joy overflowing. They bowed their heads in reverence and offered this hymn:

Great is the supreme Dao,
Vast beyond measure,
Utmost and unattainable.
Peerless, the Most High Perfected,
Without origin or beginning,
The highest and most true.
Above, it delivers the heavens,
Its transformation pervading the heights.
Below, it rescues the lost souls,
Its transformation penetrating the nether darkness,
All lingering spirits ascending.
Without master or ancestor,
No teacher, no progenitor.
The Dao alone is its body—
In praising this scripture,
The Dao is its essence.
Cinnabar Terrace and Purple Palace,
Realm of the Great Mystery’s wonders.
Golden Gates and Jade Capital—
As previously described.
Here is concealed this wondrous dharma,
Secret and treasured.
Bestowing blessings upon all beings,
Or universally delivering all.
Erasing my ten thousand sins,
This scripture extinguishes all transgressions.
Prolonging my distant years,
This scripture extends life.
Myriad spirits pay homage,
Revering this scripture.
Demon kings guard and welcome
Those who uphold it.
Virtues flourish and prosper,
Vast and all-pervading, enduring and boundless.
My name inscribed in the Yellow Register,
Recorded in the immortal ledgers of the Mystic Capital,
On golden tablets and yellow registers.
Through boundless eons,
Vast and limitless, countless kalpas.
May those who uphold this scripture endure forever.

When the assembly of Perfected Ones had finished reciting this hymn, they bowed their heads in homage, took refuge in *The Supreme Jade Emperor’s Original Acts Sutra*, and departed from the presence of the Most High Sage.

**Thus concludes the lower scroll of *The Supreme Jade Emperor’s Original Acts Sutra*.**

chunks.original_text: 高上玉皇本行经集注 经名：高上玉皇本行经集注。 简称《皇经集注》。 明全真道士周玄贞撰。 汇集宋金元明诸家《玉皇经》注，并附《玉皇心印经注》。 十卷。 底本出处：《万历续道藏》。 皇经注解卷之一 皇经集注启赞序 天猷副元帅和应善天尊制 原夫大道无刑，妙万物而资始； 至真罔象，摄群心而自归。 机若洪锺，扣之立应。 邈哉上圣，至诚遂通。 恭惟《本行经》者，玄皇之秘言，穹昊之枢要。 浮黎真境，纪谈授道之初； 紫微上宫，显露缄藏之迹。 实诸天之隐韵，乃大梵之仙章。 八角垂亡，本由於宸翰； 千真列卫，普度於人灵。 年劫孰究，世数莫知。 盖大地众生迷谬，丧失真谅，自坏刑体，耽惑情欲，不能洗涤，圣文遂隐。 今日昆山玉显，巨海珠分，获睹琼文，伏增惊叹。 所谓幽囚重系，慕妙义以荐原； 痼疾沉痾，仰德音而顿愈。 昏衢惠炬，溟渤舟航，保国宁家，济生度死。 金编玉轴，浩渺难量。 非慕真风，曷契斯理？ 聊叙大要，以化未萌云耳。 高上玉皇本行集经前序 道本无言，诸经皆真圣唾迹，但因言显道，文亦圣贤之所不废。 自三才分，名教立，理本一致，谬妄者或歧之，歧之非是也。 元始坐照於诸劫之先，当时至运会，诸真问玉帝行因，遂说是经。 乃法品最尊、灵文第一，自来经书无有及此者。 真文隐奥，不事奇丽，梵对而旨自难穷，诸圣所不能言，思议所不能到，此经括尽明若掌。 臣张仲事文中古，供职於周，柢承上帝，即闻此经，愿终宝持。 帝偶较人间功过，录臣仲在忠孝之途，命掌化九天，编辑此经。 经中玄蕴，益得饱味。 惜世观经者，不能体圣意，契玄旨，谬刊讹传，言韵或误，遂分洞玄、高上二名，各执私见以传习，大悖说经之意，甚至胶柱。 狂诞之徒，或不信此经，或以为因袭他典，或无知强解，皆不知是经之尊，而罪福报应不可逃也？ 其过何可言。 臣仲不忍盛典之失传，惜尘俗之愚谬，误犯无知不闻大道。 奏承帝命，使仙真解经说义，流传凡世，作穷经之关钥，为人道之梯阶。 庶圣经法航，可济久溺之流； 玄宗妙药，易医积沉之病。 闻经悟道，永无妄议； 应机识真，终免轮沉。 三千大千，界界悉太和之域； 从劫至劫，代代为乐利之场。 求道必得，无愿不成。 是经功德，斯无负矣。 谨序。 九天开化文昌梓橦帝君臣张仲顿首百拜。 原道 南极遐龄老人臞仙撰

**The Collected Commentaries on the Original Acts of the Supreme Jade Emperor**

**Scripture Title:** *Collected Commentaries on the Original Acts of the Supreme Jade Emperor* (Abbreviated as *Collected Commentaries on the Jade Emperor Scripture*).

Compiled by Zhou Xuanzhen, a Daoist of the Quanzhen tradition during the Ming dynasty. This work gathers commentaries on the *Jade Emperor Scripture* from the Song, Jin, Yuan, and Ming dynasties, with an appended commentary on the *Jade Emperor’s Heart Seal Scripture*. Ten fascicles in total.

**Source of the Base Text:** *Wanli Continuation of the Daoist Canon*.

---

**Fascicle One of the Commentaries on the Jade Emperor Scripture**

**Preface to the Collected Commentaries on the Jade Emperor Scripture**

Composed by the Heavenly Marshal of Harmonious Response, the Heavenly Worthy of Concordant Virtue

The Great Dao is formless, yet it subtly initiates the myriad things;
The Perfect Truth is imageless, yet it gathers the hearts of all to return of their own accord.
Its mechanism is like a great bell—struck, it responds at once.
How vast is the Supreme Sage! Sincerity alone suffices to commune with it.

We reverently regard the *Original Acts Scripture* as the secret words of the Mysterious Emperor, the pivotal essence of the boundless heavens.
In the Floating Black True Realm, it records the first transmission of the Dao;
In the Purple Tenuity Upper Palace, it reveals the traces of its sealed mysteries.
Truly, it is the hidden melody of all heavens, the immortal verses of the Great Brahmā.
When the Eight Trigrams faced ruin, it was due to the imperial brush;
When the thousand perfected stood in guard, it universally delivered the numinous spirits of humanity.
Who can fathom its kalpas? Who can know its ages?
For the multitudes of the great earth, deluded and lost, have forsaken their true nature, destroyed their original forms, and indulged in sensual desires, unable to cleanse themselves—thus the sacred text remained hidden.

Today, as jade emerges from Kun Mountain and pearls divide from the vast sea, we have obtained this luminous scripture, prostrating in awe and wonder.
It is said: those imprisoned in darkness, yearning for its wondrous meaning, may be redeemed at the source;
Those afflicted with chronic illness, gazing upon its virtuous resonance, may be instantly cured.
It is a torch in the gloom, a vessel upon the abyss—preserving the state, pacifying the household, aiding the living, and delivering the dead.
Inscribed on golden tablets and jade scrolls, its vastness is beyond measure.
Without reverence for the true wind, how can one grasp this principle?
I humbly set forth its essentials to enlighten those yet unenlightened.

---

**Preface to the Collected Scripture on the Original Acts of the Supreme Jade Emperor**

The Dao is fundamentally wordless, yet all scriptures are the traces of true sages’ discourse. Words reveal the Dao, and even sages and worthies do not abandon them.
Since the division of the Three Powers and the establishment of the teachings of names, principle has remained unified—yet the deluded may diverge from it, and divergence is not the Way.

Before the kalpas began, the Primordial Beginning sat in illumination. When the time and destiny were ripe, the perfected ones inquired of the Jade Emperor regarding his causal acts, and thus he expounded this scripture.
It is the most venerable of dharma categories, the foremost of numinous texts—no scripture since has equaled it.
Its true words are profound and recondite, eschewing ornate embellishment. Though its Brahmā-verse is self-contained, its purport is inexhaustible; even the sages cannot speak of it, nor can thought or contemplation reach it. Yet this scripture encompasses all, as clear as the palm of one’s hand.

Your servant, Zhang Zhong, served in the civil administration of the Zhou dynasty, entrusted with affairs by the Supreme Emperor. Upon hearing this scripture, he vowed to treasure and uphold it to the end.
When the Emperor reviewed the merits and transgressions of humanity, he recorded that your servant Zhong walked the path of loyalty and filial piety, and commanded him to oversee the transformation of the Nine Heavens and compile this scripture.
Within its profound mysteries, he savored its richness to the fullest.

Alas! Those who study this scripture in the world fail to embody the sagely intent, to grasp the profound essence. Erroneous carvings and misguided transmissions have led to distortions in its verses, splitting it into two names—*Cavernous Mystery* and *Supreme*—each clinging to private interpretations in transmission, greatly deviating from the intent of the scripture’s exposition. Some even adhere rigidly like tuning pegs to a zither.
The reckless and absurd may disbelieve this scripture, or claim it borrows from other texts, or force interpretations in ignorance—all unaware of the scripture’s supremacy, and that the retributions of blessings and misfortunes cannot be escaped. How grievous is their error!

Your servant Zhong could not bear the loss of this magnificent canon, nor the folly of the vulgar world, which, in ignorance, offends without hearing the Great Dao.
He memorialized the Emperor’s command, enlisting immortal perfected ones to explicate the scripture’s meaning, disseminating it among the mortal realm as the key to exhaustive study and the ladder to the human Dao.
May this sacred canon serve as a vessel, rescuing those long drowned;
May this wondrous medicine of the Mysterious Tradition readily cure chronic ailments.
Those who hear the scripture and awaken to the Dao shall never speak recklessly;
Those who respond to the moment and recognize the true shall forever escape the wheel of rebirth.
Across the three thousand great thousand worlds, every realm shall become a domain of supreme harmony;
From kalpa to kalpa, every generation shall be a scene of joy and benefit.
Those who seek the Dao shall surely attain it; no wish shall go unfulfilled.
The merit of this scripture shall thus be without fail.

I respectfully inscribe this preface.

**Zhang Zhong, Minister of the Nine Heavens’ Civilizing Transformation and the Venerable Emperor of Literary Florescence, prostrates and bows a hundred times.**

---

**On the Original Dao**

Composed by the Venerable Immortal of the Southern Culmen, the Aged Recluse
