chunks.original_text: 奉戒专一，冥心大道，清斋弘誓，千万劫中，尊奉玉帝。 冲虚帝君云：尔夜光祈圣慈开未悟之时，元始天尊，谓夜光玉女言：汝固初得入於圣流。 汝，尔也。 圣流，与圣人同行列，作一流类也。 既为圣矣，宜无不知。 柰初入圣流，虽有睿智聪慧，尚未能大明了彻。 此诸侍卫玉帝之玉女，非一旦有此神通也。 乃自过去往昔无尽量劫数中，修众妙行，全具大解悟超脱之门，历劫无染，永不退正信心。 玉帝夙修，常清净信矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净信也。 不着色象，得大解脱。 玉帝夙修，常清浄解矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净解也。 真念无生，脱尽诸趣。 玉帝夙修，常清净念矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净念也。 妙行庄严，永无过动。 玉帝夙修，常清净行矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净行也。 道以物身，不染邪秽。 玉帝夙修，常清净身矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净身也。 心即道、道即心，湛然无住。 玉帝夙修，常清净心矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净心也。 无内外，无将迎，绝意忘机。 玉帝夙修，常清净意矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净意也。 位乎上清，永不退转。 玉帝证圣，得清净果矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净果也。 浩劫推崇，功德莫量。 玉帝至尊，得清净报矣。 诸玉女往劫妙行，亦同此清净报也。 仁周沙界，惠孚浩劫。 玉帝具大慈心矣。 诸玉女妙行，亦同此大慈心也。 万有群生，悉加矜怜。 玉帝具大悲心矣。 诸玉女妙行，亦同此大悲心也。 玉女大慈悲，心同玉帝。 其实云何？ 覆盖保护众生，如慈母抚育惜念，恩爱赤心之幼子； 且奉持玄戒，专笃诚一。 或云，钦奉心、严戒心，精专纯一，故冥心诚皈大道。 意更妙。 诸玉女皈大道非暂然，清净齐虔，弘大誓愿，千万劫中，历来钦奉尊敬玉帝。 愚按：人有正信心，自然解悟，念断行纯，身无所染，心清意净，证果获报，必得至真。 能大慈悲，严持妙戒，对越上帝，历久不回，则上仙可至。 世人惑邪见，杂念僻行，身不能修，心扰意乱，果报牵缠，皆以不慈悲、弗信道也。 故夜光初入圣流，尚不能悉诸玉女妙行，则与之同行，益难矣。 意，道人人有也，善反之，则玉女之妙行在我。 神通品二十四章 此诸玉女非实是女，皆天至真，为度群生，现玉女身。 是故身色神通，智慧隐显，变化与帝同焉。 尔时，夜光闻是说已，心得开悟，稽首欢喜，默然复位。 关尹子云：此侍卫玉帝、往昔无量劫修诸妙行之玉女，非真是女身，皆天仙至真，为化度法界群生入道，遂化现玉女之身。 惟其为至真之化身，身素非女，是故身色、神通、智慧，隐显变化，非浅鲜也，与玉帝伺焉。 凡人莫不有身，色身幻体不能分化，难以与玉帝同身。 至於变身之魔鬼，身为矫阵，又不足言。 上有天人，或五里，或数里，或一二由旬，或百亿万丈，或在天宫，或见真界，或着人间。 一显於此，不能他化。 或着闻见，不能妙度，拘一处，限一时，皆非最上妙化法身。 诸玉女化身遍见一切世界，聚散自如，卓绝伦类，是身与玉帝同。 有身皆为色，色不妙好，或美而罔终，皆非色於帝同。 诸玉女化身妙色，端奇美好，随在全彰，永无变迁。 是色与帝同。
chunks.translated_text:
Upholding the precepts with single-minded devotion, they inwardly align with the Great Dao, observe pure fasts, and uphold vast vows. Through myriad kalpas, they have revered the Jade Emperor with utmost devotion.

The Sovereign of Primordial Emptiness declared: When you, Moonlight, first beseeched the sagely compassion to dispel your unenlightened state, the Primordial Heavenly Venerable addressed you, saying: You have only recently entered the sagely stream. *You*—that is, *you*. *Sagely stream* means to stand in the same rank and company as the sages, forming one category with them. Having become a sage, one should know all things. Yet, having only newly entered the sagely stream, though possessing keen wisdom and intelligence, you have not yet attained full clarity and thorough understanding.

These Jade Maidens who attend and guard the Jade Emperor did not acquire their divine powers in a single day. Rather, from immeasurable kalpas past, they have cultivated manifold wondrous practices, fully attained the gates of great awakening and liberation, passed through kalpas unstained, and never retreated from the mind of true faith. The Jade Emperor’s long cultivation has always been in pure faith, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure faith.

Unattached to form and appearance, they have attained great liberation. The Jade Emperor’s long cultivation has always been in pure understanding, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure understanding.

With true mindfulness of the unborn, they have transcended all destinies. The Jade Emperor’s long cultivation has always been in pure mindfulness, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure mindfulness.

Their wondrous practices adorn them, forever free from transgression or disturbance. The Jade Emperor’s long cultivation has always been in pure conduct, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure conduct.

The Dao embodies the physical form, unstained by defilement or impurity. The Jade Emperor’s long cultivation has always been in a pure body, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure body.

Mind is the Dao, and the Dao is mind—lucid and unattached. The Jade Emperor’s long cultivation has always been in a pure mind, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure mind.

Without inside or outside, without approach or reception, they have severed intentions and forgotten scheming. The Jade Emperor’s long cultivation has always been in a pure intention, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure intention.

Abiding in the Upper Clarity, they never regress. The Jade Emperor, having attained sagehood, has realized the pure fruit, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure fruit.

Through vast kalpas, their merit is exalted beyond measure. The Jade Emperor, as the Most High, has received the pure retribution, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices in past kalpas are likewise in this pure retribution.

Their benevolence pervades the dust-mote realms, and their kindness extends through boundless kalpas. The Jade Emperor possesses great compassion, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices are likewise in this great compassion.

All myriad beings receive their tender care and pity. The Jade Emperor possesses great mercy, and the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices are likewise in this great mercy.

The Jade Maidens’ great compassion and mercy are one with the Jade Emperor’s. But how is this so? They shelter and protect sentient beings as a loving mother cherishes and tenderly cares for her infant child with a heart of redoubled affection. Moreover, they uphold the mysterious precepts with unwavering sincerity and single-minded devotion. Some say: reverently upholding the mind and strictly observing the precepts, they concentrate with utter purity and unity, thus inwardly and sincerely returning to the Great Dao. The meaning is even more profound.

The Jade Maidens’ return to the Great Dao is not momentary. With pure and solemn devotion, they uphold vast vows, and through myriad kalpas, they have always revered and honored the Jade Emperor.

This foolish one observes: Those who possess the mind of true faith will naturally attain understanding and awakening, sever deluded thoughts, purify their conduct, keep their bodies unstained, their minds clear, and their intentions pure. They will realize the fruit and receive retribution, ultimately attaining the utmost truth. Those who embody great compassion and mercy, strictly uphold wondrous precepts, and reverently serve the Supreme Emperor without wavering through the ages may ascend to the rank of Upper Immortals.

Yet worldly people, deluded by heterodox views, harbor杂念 and perverse conduct. They fail to cultivate their bodies, their minds are disturbed, and their intentions are chaotic. Their karmic retributions entangle them, all because they lack compassion and do not believe in the Dao. Thus, though Moonlight has newly entered the sagely stream, she still cannot fully comprehend the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices. To walk the same path as they do is even more difficult.

The Dao is inherent in all people. If one reflects upon and cultivates it well, the Jade Maidens’ wondrous practices may be realized within oneself.

**Chapter Twenty-Four on Divine Powers**

These Jade Maidens are not truly women; they are celestial perfected beings who, to deliver sentient beings, manifest as Jade Maidens. Therefore, their bodily forms, divine powers, wisdom, and transformations—whether hidden or revealed—are equal to the Emperor’s.

At that time, upon hearing these words, Moonlight attained awakening. She bowed her head in reverence, rejoiced, and silently returned to her place.

Master Guan Yin said: These Jade Maidens who attend the Jade Emperor, having cultivated manifold wondrous practices through immeasurable kalpas past, are not truly female in form. They are celestial immortals and perfected beings who, to transform and guide sentient beings of the Dharma realms into the Dao, manifest as Jade Maidens. Precisely because they are the transformed bodies of perfected beings—whose original forms are not female—their bodily appearance, divine powers, wisdom, and transformations, whether hidden or revealed, are not superficial but equal to the Jade Emperor’s.

All people possess bodies, yet the illusory nature of the physical form cannot divide or transform. Thus, it is difficult to share the same body as the Jade Emperor. As for the shape-shifting demons and ghosts, their bodies are deceptive and illusory, and thus not worth mentioning.

Among the celestial beings above, some may extend five *li*, or several *li*, or one or two *yojanas*, or hundreds of millions of *zhang*. Some reside in heavenly palaces, some perceive the true realm, and some appear among humans. Yet when they manifest in one place, they cannot transform elsewhere. Or, though perceptible to the senses, they cannot skillfully deliver beings, bound as they are to one location or one moment. None of these are the most supreme, wondrous Dharma bodies of transformation.

The transformed bodies of the Jade Maidens appear throughout all worlds, gathering and dispersing at will, surpassing all others. Their bodies are equal to the Jade Emperor’s. All bodies are composed of form, yet if form is not wondrously refined—or if it is beautiful but not enduring—it is not equal to the Emperor’s form. The transformed bodies of the Jade Maidens possess wondrous beauty, majestic and exquisite, fully manifesting wherever they appear, never changing or declining. Their form is equal to the Emperor’s.

chunks.original_text: 天人魔道，皆有神通，神化有限，通非六运，是神通不与帝同矣。 诸玉女神化无方，悉且六通，是神通与帝同。 神人皆有智慧，有隔碍，未明了，或假体照，不能妙会，非智慧与帝伺。 诸玉女彻照无遗，预通无碍，是智慧与帝同。 知神通者悉善隐，隐有遗迹，非与帝同也。 诸玉女散则还於太虚，不但芥纳须弥，是妙隐无迹，隐与帝同。 有隐则有显，显非大光，未与帝同也诸玉女妙现清微，神见各界，是显与帝同。 有神通智慧隐显，是能变化。 变化若假作为，非与帝同。 诸玉女妙变无心，神化自然，是变化与帝同。 此时夜光闻元始说诸玉女现化语意已竟，心中便得开明觉悟，知诸玉女妙化因由，稽首作礼，欢悦喜庆，默然忘言，复归本位。 愚按：人身阴阳，非判然二物，自一而二，阴以孕阳，阳以生阴，本至根也。 修真成道，六丁阴神化见玉女，妙变。 奇机与元神玄灵同功。 此阴化呈灵，岂独坤质，延乾体孕育，阳光梵炁之化耳。 况天上神真变化无定，教度众生，各有权宜。 应以男身，即现男形； 应以女身，即化女体。 劫运甚久，世界纷然。 应以女身度者，不可限量。 此天上至圣神真化诸玉女以度群生，其身色、神通、智慧隐显变化，非神人所及，与玉帝同。 夜光虽朝三清境界，夙闻法音，初入圣流。 此大神通至真妙行，宜其未知。 虽然，圣凡同性，则法身一般，有普济之心，效至真之行。 诸玉女同帝神妙，在吾身矣。 故夜光闻说，了悟欢喜也。 达者详之。 皇经注解卷三竟 皇经注解卷四 嗣汉五十代天师大真人张国祥校 状元方外隐江西吉水罗洪先阅 山东济南小兆臣周玄贞集 神通品二十五

The paths of heavenly beings, demons, and humans all possess spiritual penetrations, yet their transformations are limited, their powers not encompassing the six penetrations—such spiritual penetrations are not equal to the Emperor’s. The Jade Maidens’ divine transformations are boundless, fully possessing the six penetrations; thus, their spiritual penetrations are equal to the Emperor’s.

Divine beings all possess wisdom, yet it is obstructed, not fully illuminated, or relies on borrowed perception, unable to achieve wondrous convergence—such wisdom is not equal to the Emperor’s. The Jade Maidens perceive all without omission, their foresight unobstructed; thus, their wisdom is equal to the Emperor’s.

Those who know spiritual penetrations may all conceal themselves, yet concealment leaves traces—this is not equal to the Emperor’s. When the Jade Maidens disperse, they return to the Great Void, not merely containing Mount Sumeru within a mustard seed; their wondrous concealment leaves no trace, their concealment equal to the Emperor’s.

Where there is concealment, there is manifestation, yet manifestation is not the great radiance—this is not equal to the Emperor’s. The Jade Maidens wondrously manifest in the pure and subtle, their divine perception spanning all realms; thus, their manifestation is equal to the Emperor’s.

Possessing spiritual penetrations, wisdom, concealment, and manifestation enables transformation. Yet if transformation is contrived, it is not equal to the Emperor’s. The Jade Maidens’ wondrous transformations arise without intention, their divine transformations spontaneous; thus, their transformations are equal to the Emperor’s.

At that moment, Yeguang, having heard the Primordial Beginning’s discourse on the Jade Maidens’ manifestations and transformations, attained clarity and awakening in his heart. He understood the wondrous causes of the Jade Maidens’ transformations, bowed in reverence, and rejoiced with delight. Silently, he forgot speech and returned to his original position.

A foolish note: The yin and yang of the human body are not two distinctly separate entities but arise from one, becoming two—yin nurtures yang, and yang generates yin, rooted in the utmost origin. Cultivating truth to attain the Dao, the six yin spirits transform and manifest as Jade Maidens, wondrously changing. This marvelous mechanism shares the same function as the primordial spirit and mysterious numen. This yin transformation revealing numinosity is not unique to the earthly quality; it extends to the heavenly body’s nurturing, the transformation of yang’s radiance and Brahman qi. Moreover, the divine immortals of heaven transform without fixed form, teaching and delivering beings according to expedient means. When a male form is needed, they manifest as male; when a female form is required, they transform into female. Through countless kalpas, worlds abound in multiplicity. Those who ought to be delivered by a female form are beyond measure. Thus, the supreme divine immortals of heaven transform into Jade Maidens to deliver multitudes. Their bodily form, spiritual penetrations, wisdom, concealment, manifestation, and transformations surpass all divine beings and are equal to the Jade Emperor’s. Though Yeguang had visited the Three Pure Realms and long heard the Dharma’s sound, he had only recently entered the sacred stream. Such great spiritual penetrations and supreme, wondrous practices were naturally unknown to him. Nevertheless, the sacred and the profane share the same nature, and the Dharma body is universal. With a heart for universal salvation and emulation of the utmost truth, the Jade Maidens’ divine wondrousness equal to the Emperor’s resides within our own bodies. Thus, Yeguang, upon hearing this discourse, attained understanding and rejoiced. Those who comprehend should reflect deeply.

chunks.original_text: 尔时，高虚清明天主与诸天眷属驭八景鸾舆，九光宝盖，奏玄歌妙乐，咏无量洞章，散天宝花，喷天真香，飞步游空，来诣道前。 承天尊玉帝威神之力，是诸宝花即於空中化一宝盖，荫覆大众，无不周徧。 赤松子云：尔夜光玉女复位之时，高虚清明天帝主与本天诸亲春属类，或作别天主春属，非也。 清明天主与眷属来时，各驾八景辉明鸾舆，九霞光耀宝盖。 八景，一作八宝妙景，一作八卦神景，一作八色光景。 大抵天上神舆，凋八方之景，备八节之和，故云八景。 奏太玄歌神妙之乐，咏无量功三洞宝章，遍散天宝奇花，喷着天真妙香，飞步凌虚，游空而来，敬诣道前，承元始天尊玉帝威德神通之力，此众宝花，即於虚空中化一宝盖，荫庇覆盖法会大众，无有不周遍处。 愚按：人之修真，朝上帝，礼元皇，默转真经，清虚神光，后朝玄境时呈秘妙，琼花结彩，周覆众妙。 皆虚皇秘引，元神慈接。 即高虚清明天主后至法筵，呈妙乐，御灵舆，所散天花，仗元始玉帝威力，成宝盖覆众无遗也。 有志者，观此典而神会之，则天上景化，一身具之矣。 神通品二十六章 是时，高虚清明天主见此希有，稽首长跪，白天尊玉帝言：贱臣懈怠，后会法筵。 今日吉庆，值遇法桥，幽显圣凡，普沾圣泽，放大光明，现希有相，上照诸天。 四梵六欲，一切乐土诸真圣众，睹此光明，悉皆云集。 下照下方无极世界，同玄都境，近接九天，灵风奏乐，宫商相和，激朗云庭，皆成洞章。 一切众生，咸臻道化。 酆都铁围，长夜九幽，一切地狱受苦众生尽承光力，皆生诸天，得受快乐。 今日所散天宝奇花旋结成盖，徧覆法筵。 大会诸众尽承斯光威神之力。 臣等千劫良因，九天运会，皇道荡荡，正法兴隆，今日大吉，成仰玄功。 火帝真君云：是宝花成盖、遍覆大众之时，高虚清明天主见此希有之事，稽首长跪，上白元始天尊、玉皇大帝，自己谦言，卑贱下臣，懈惰怠慢，后期迟会於法筵。 今日吉辰庆霄，值遇尊圣慈济法桥。 桥者，世人建之，以济水津，免徒涉。 但凡世桥梁，须木石构成，且所济有限，易於损坏，如长江大河湖海皆不能济。 至圣经功法力，济浩劫，周沙界，不假作为、形迹，潜移默转，秘化神通，使人出爱河，离欲海，免血湖，祛洪灾，永久不毁，故曰法桥。 幽而冥途，显而阳界。 圣智凡愚，普同沾濡至圣恩泽。

At that time, the Lord of the High Void and Pure Brightness Heaven, together with his celestial retinue, rode the eight-scene simurgh chariot, beneath nine-rayed jeweled canopies. They performed the Mysterious Song and wondrous music, chanted the boundless Cavern Chapters, scattered celestial treasure flowers, and sprayed celestial perfected incense. Ascending in flight, they traversed the void and arrived before the Dao.

By the awe-inspiring power and virtue of the Heavenly Worthy and Jade Emperor, these myriad treasure flowers instantly transformed in midair into a single jeweled canopy, shading and covering the great assembly without exception.

The Master Red Pine said: When Yeguang Jade Maiden returned to her position, the Lord of the High Void and Pure Brightness Heaven, along with the celestial kin of his own heaven—or, as some mistakenly claim, the kin of another heaven—arrived. As the Lord of Pure Brightness Heaven and his retinue came, each rode the eight-scene radiant simurgh chariot beneath nine-cloud luminous jeweled canopies. The "eight scenes" are also called the eight treasured wondrous scenes, the eight trigram divine scenes, or the eight-hued luminous scenes. Generally, the divine chariots of heaven gather the scenes of the eight directions and embody the harmony of the eight solar terms, hence the term "eight scenes." They performed the Great Mysterious Song and spirit-wondrous music, chanted the boundless merit of the Three Cavern treasure chapters, scattered celestial treasure flowers in all directions, sprayed celestial perfected incense, and, stepping upon the void, traversed the heavens to arrive respectfully before the Dao.

By the awe-inspiring power, virtue, and divine penetrations of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy and Jade Emperor, these multitude of treasure flowers instantly transformed in the void into a single jeweled canopy, shading and sheltering the great assembly of the Dharma gathering without omission.

This fool observes: When mortals cultivate the truth, pay homage to the Supreme Emperor, revere the Primordial Sovereign, and silently recite the true scriptures, their pure void spirit-light will, upon later audience in the mysterious realm, manifest secret wonders—jade flowers forming canopies, universally covering all wondrous beings. All this is the secret guidance of the Void Sovereign and the compassionate reception of the primordial spirit. Thus, when the Lord of the High Void and Pure Brightness Heaven later arrived at the Dharma banquet, presenting wondrous music and riding the numinous chariot, the celestial flowers he scattered, by the power of the Primordial Heavenly Worthy and Jade Emperor, formed a jeweled canopy covering all without exception. Those of aspiration who contemplate this canon and spiritually comprehend it will find that the wondrous transformations of heaven are fully possessed within their own bodies.

*Chapter on Spiritual Penetrations, Twenty-Six*

At that time, the Lord of the High Void and Pure Brightness Heaven, beholding this rare spectacle, prostrated himself and knelt in reverence, addressing the Heavenly Worthy and Jade Emperor: "This humble servant, indolent and remiss, arrived late to the Dharma assembly. Today, on this auspicious occasion, I have encountered the Dharma Bridge. The hidden and the manifest, the sacred and the profane, all universally partake of the sagely grace. A great radiance shines forth, revealing rare and wondrous signs, illuminating all heavens above. The Four Brahmā Heavens and Six Desire Realms, all the blessed lands and assemblies of perfected sages, beholding this radiance, gather in clouds. Below, it shines upon the boundless worlds of the lower realms, uniting with the Mysterious Capital, closely adjoining the Nine Heavens. Divine winds perform music, harmonizing palace and note, resonating brightly through the cloud courts, all transforming into Cavern Chapters. All beings universally attain the transformation of the Dao.

In the Fengdu Iron Enclosure, the eternal night of the Nine Dark Realms, all suffering beings in the hells, by the power of this light, are reborn in the heavens and enjoy bliss. Today, the scattered celestial treasure flowers swiftly coalesced into a canopy, universally covering the Dharma assembly. All in the great congregation partake of the power and awe-inspiring might of this light. Through a thousand kalpas of good causes and the cyclical movements of the Nine Heavens, the imperial Dao flows boundlessly, and the true Dharma flourishes. Today is most auspicious, as we behold and revere the mysterious merit."

The True Lord of Fire said: When the treasure flowers formed a canopy covering all, the Lord of the High Void and Pure Brightness Heaven, witnessing this rare event, prostrated himself and knelt, humbly addressing the Primordial Heavenly Worthy and Jade Emperor. He spoke of himself as a lowly and indolent servant, tardy in attending the Dharma assembly. Today, on this auspicious occasion, he encountered the compassionate salvation of the sagely Dharma Bridge. Bridges in the world are built by mortals to span waterways, sparing them from fording. Yet even the finest worldly bridges, constructed of wood and stone, have limited reach and are prone to decay; they cannot span great rivers, lakes, or seas. But the power of the sagely scriptures and Dharma transcends kalpas, pervades the cosmos, and requires no fabrication or trace. Through subtle transformation and secret divine penetrations, it enables beings to escape the river of love, depart the sea of desire, avoid the blood lake, and dispel great calamities—eternally indestructible, hence called the Dharma Bridge. It spans the hidden paths of darkness and the manifest realms of light. The sagely and the foolish, the wise and the ignorant, all universally partake of its sagely grace.

chunks.original_text: 玉帝放普照大光明，现希有神妙相，上照各界诸天，四梵六欲等天，一切快乐净土，诸仙真神圣众等睹见此大光明，悉皆云合集会。 云之合也，倏忽满空，不知何来。 圣众速集如云，故曰云集。 其光下照下方无极量世界，俱同清微天玄都境界，近迩神接联九宸上天。 光中灵风，奏天妙乐，如宫调商音相和。 凡乐宫商等五音，虽分清浊，别五行，天然之妙，或未易有。 帝天灵风，妙和自然，不啻凡乐，是宫商相和，激扬朗震於云庭，皆成三洞宝章。 下方诸世界一切众生，咸臻集大道玄化。 酆都狱，铁围城，长夜九幽，一切地狱受苦众生尽仰承玉帝大光明法力，皆生诸天宫，得受快乐。 今日臣所散天宝奇花旋绕结成华盖，徧覆冒法筵大会诸众，尽仰承天尊玉帝大光威德神力。 臣清明天主等，非止一世之幸，遇此希有，千万劫中，多修良因，又值九天嘉运聚会，皇天至道荡荡坦平，重玄正法兴行隆盛。 一云，元始开化，演最上法，皇风沕穆，大道平平，时无旁门外道，适正法兴隆之际。 意亦可。 今日庆霄，是大吉辰。 诸界神人、一切群生咸得仰赖最玄功化。 一云，咸欲仰希玄功，俯陈道要，亦可。 愚按：人身虽小，包罗天地，万有悉具，众妙浑涵，清虚灵气，分司六阳，亦有高虚清明天主。 若元神失御，玄化未呈，则趣溺恩波，机沉苦海，洪津巨浪，滔滔靡岸，何以免沦没，拯昏垫也？ 惟一人浸淫，遂沦胥陷溺，误己误他，固不足论。 其滞於小乘，惑於旁径，行潦无源，难免枯涸，又不足道。 间或浚灵源，接道脉，浸浸几化矣。 而自屯其膏，恩泽不降，又非大成耳。 故有证四梵六欲之果，不达九宸七宝之境，或受人中福报，或作狱主魔王，甚至沉三恶道，沦九幽界，可哀莫大焉。 是以灵化不彰，妙韵不露，真经失转。 琼花无彩，由不作良因，不信正法。 兹不能闻荡荡平平之道，而仰被玄功也。 能凝玄神，泰天君，清虚明妙之灵，后机随发，则通达曹溪，吸尽西江，融会金液，诞登道岸，苦海业坑，永得消灭，超绝六欲，高出四梵，普会万神，照彻幽界。 灵风鼓真，妙韵绝品，真经默转以无停，万有蒙恩於不匮。 酆都破围，九幽开光，地狱化天堂，罪众生净土。 一身阴浊，悉变阳明； 琼花霞彩，盖荫众妙。 实虚皇之灵，元神之力也。 非积修素养，正法笃信，何以聆皇道休风，得仰玄功哉？ 噫，此身之妙真也，视清明天主后至法筵，庆遇法桥。 称圣化，扬玄功，谓道济天地幽显者同矣。 而修良因，广妙行，不求速化，妙本自然，又证圣真诀也。 学道者味之自得。 神通品二十七章 是时， 是法会圣众咸仰玄功之时。 高虚清明天主， 解见前。 以偈赞玉帝曰： 清明天主。 以偈语赞玉帝曰。 金阙玄穹祖， 祖，一本作主字。 考经意，玉帝为天主，诸佛师，御黄金阙，为玄都穹苍宗老，故云祖。 或作主字，是但以天帝言矣。 高上玉皇尊， 解见前。 妙相冠诸天， 诸天神人。 皆有美相，或衰毁有穷，或神通有限，随各居之天，变化不能相兼，色相容颜，未甚超绝。 玉帝随形妙好，无量无边，色相奇妙，独冠诸天。 慈光烛三界。 大慈光明，照彻上天、下地、人问，故云普烛三界。 真圣妙道师， 真一至圣神妙大道玄师。
chunks.translated_text:
The Jade Emperor radiates the Great Illuminating Brilliance, manifesting a rare and wondrous divine form. Its light ascends to illumine all heavens of every realm—the Four Brahmā Heavens, the Six Desire Heavens, and every blissful pure land. All the immortals, perfected beings, divine sages, and holy assemblies behold this great radiance and gather like clouds in assembly. The clouds converge in an instant, filling the sky, their origin unknown. The holy hosts swiftly gather like clouds, hence called "cloud assembly." The light descends to illumine the boundless worlds below, all of which become as the Pure Subtlety Heaven’s Mystic Capital, closely linked in spirit to the Nine Celestial Upper Heavens. Within the light, a divine breeze plays celestial melodies, harmonizing as palace modes and shang tones blend. Though the five notes—palace, shang, and the rest—distinguish clarity and turbidity and correspond to the Five Phases, their natural wonder is not easily matched. The Emperor’s divine breeze harmonizes exquisitely of itself, far surpassing mortal music. As palace and shang tones resonate, they stir and resound through the cloud courts, transforming into the precious chapters of the Three Caverns. All beings in the worlds below universally attain the mysterious transformation of the Great Dao.

In the Fengdu prisons, the Iron-Walled Citadel, the eternal night of the Nine Dark Realms, and all the hells, suffering beings look up to receive the power of the Jade Emperor’s great illuminating Dharma. They are all reborn in the heavenly palaces, where they enjoy bliss. Today, the celestial treasures and wondrous flowers I have scattered swirl and weave into a floral canopy, universally covering and sheltering all assembled at this Dharma feast. All look up to receive the majestic power and divine virtue of the Heavenly Worthy Jade Emperor.

We, the Lords of the Pure Clarity Heaven, are not merely fortunate in this single lifetime to encounter such a rarity. Through countless kalpas, we have cultivated good causes, and now we meet the auspicious convergence of the Nine Heavens, where the imperial Dao of Heaven flows vast and level, and the profound and wondrous true Dharma flourishes in full splendor.

One version states: When the Primordial Beginning initiated transformation and expounded the supreme Dharma, the imperial wind was profound and serene, the Great Dao level and even. At that time, no heterodox paths existed, and the true Dharma flourished in its prime. This meaning is also acceptable.

Today’s celebration in the celestial realm is a most auspicious occasion. All divine beings and every living creature universally receive and rely upon the most mysterious transformative power.

Another version states: All desire to look up in hope of the mysterious power and humbly present the essentials of the Dao. This is also acceptable.

In my humble opinion: Though the human body is small, it encompasses Heaven and Earth, contains the myriad existences, and embraces all wonders. The pure, empty, and numinous qi governs the six yang, and there is also the Lord of the High, Empty, Pure Clarity Heaven. If the primordial spirit loses its governance and the mysterious transformation does not manifest, one is drawn into the waves of affection, sunk in the sea of suffering. The vast currents and towering waves surge without end—how can one avoid drowning and rescue those lost in darkness?

When even one person is steeped in delusion, they sink and drag others down with them, leading both astray—a matter not worth discussing. Those who stagnate in the Lesser Vehicle or are deluded by side paths, like flowing water without a source, cannot escape drying up—this, too, is not worth mentioning. Occasionally, one dredges the wellspring of the numinous and connects with the pulse of the Dao, gradually nearing transformation. Yet if one hoards their own richness and fails to let virtue descend, this is not the great accomplishment.

Thus, some attain the fruits of the Four Brahmā or Six Desire Heavens but do not reach the Nine Celestial or Seven Treasures realms. Some receive blessings among humans, or become lords of hells or demon kings. Some even sink into the Three Evil Paths or are lost in the Nine Dark Realms—what sorrow could be greater? When the numinous transformation is not manifest and the wondrous resonance is not revealed, the true scriptures fail to circulate. The jade-like flowers lose their luster because one has not cultivated good causes or believed in the true Dharma. Thus, one cannot hear the vast and level Dao or look up to receive the mysterious power.

If one can concentrate the mysterious spirit, stabilize the Heavenly Lord, and embody the pure, empty, and wondrously numinous, then when the later mechanism is activated, one will penetrate the Cao Creek, drink the entire Western River, merge with the golden liquid, and ascend the shore of the Dao. The sea of suffering and the pit of karma will be forever extinguished. One will transcend the Six Desires, rise above the Four Brahmā, universally unite with the myriad spirits, and illumine the dark realms. The divine breeze stirs the true, the wondrous resonance is peerless, and the true scriptures silently circulate without cease. The myriad existences receive boundless grace. Fengdu’s walls are breached, the Nine Dark Realms are illuminated, hells transform into heavens, and sinful beings become pure lands. The yin turbidity of the body entirely shifts to yang clarity; jade-like flowers radiate rosy hues, sheltering all wonders. This is truly the numinous power of the August Emperor and the force of the primordial spirit. Without accumulating cultivation and nurturing the true Dharma with unwavering faith, how could one hear the auspicious wind of the imperial Dao or look up to receive the mysterious power?

Alas! The wondrous truth of this body is revealed when we, the Lords of the Pure Clarity Heaven, arrive late at the Dharma feast and celebrate the encounter with the Dharma Bridge. To praise the sagely transformation and extol the mysterious power is to say that the Dao universally saves the dark and the manifest alike. Yet to cultivate good causes, broaden wondrous practices, not seek hasty transformation, and let the wondrous root arise naturally—this is the secret of attaining sagely perfection. Those who study the Dao should savor this and realize it for themselves.

**Chapter on Spiritual Penetrations, Verse 27**

At this time, as the holy assembly all look up to receive the mysterious power, the Lord of the High, Empty, Pure Clarity Heaven—explained previously—praises the Jade Emperor in verse:

The Lord of the Pure Clarity Heaven praises the Jade Emperor in verse:

Golden Portal, Mystic Vault Ancestor,
*(Ancestor: One version reads "Lord." Considering the scripture’s meaning, the Jade Emperor is the Lord of Heaven, teacher of all buddhas, and ruler of the Golden Portal, the venerable elder of the Mystic Capital’s vaulted heavens, hence called "Ancestor." If rendered as "Lord," it refers only to the Heavenly Emperor.)*

Supreme Jade Emperor Worthy,
*(Explained previously.)*

Wondrous form crowns all heavens,
*(All divine beings in the heavens possess fine forms, but some may decline or be limited in their transformations. Each resides in their own heaven and cannot assume all forms; their appearances and countenances are not supremely transcendent. The Jade Emperor’s form is wondrously excellent without limit, his appearance and countenance uniquely surpassing all heavens.)*

Compassionate light illumines the Three Realms.
*(His great compassionate radiance illumines the heavens above, the earth below, and the human realm in between, hence called "universally illumines the Three Realms.")*

True Sage, Wondrous Dao’s Master.

chunks.original_text: 一云，玉帝之行，真圣玄妙，道宗尊师也。 天人依仗师。 玉帝为天人教主、万神之君、上天神圣。 世间人民皆宗依，仰仗功化，是天人师。 大乘垂法语， 道法三乘，分上、中、下。 又有最上一乘，不依阶级，高超三品，并包无遗，是为大乘。 诸神法语，各随智见。 大乘希闻。 玉帝垂教，明示真宗，彻上彻下，该括诸品。 群生蒙诲，悉得超脱，是大乘垂法语 真一指迷途。 玉帝以真宗玄一妙理，指明开悟迷途，此直指单传，使人不落旁门小法。 即指人以大路，使之不陷邪径也。 功德若虚空， 天下之物，皆有穷尽。 惟虚空历劫若是，再无改移。 玉帝大功至德，无量无边，如同虚空，不可穷极。 诸神圣非无功德，或远或近，或小或大，可以随分比拟。 玉帝功德，无有比伦，故若虚空。 赞扬无穷尽。 玉帝功德如虚空，称赞难穷，皈依莫尽，赞扬无穷尽，盛德不可名称矣。 黄石公云：高虚清明天主虽后会法筵，真见玉帝妙化，神景奇观，仰慕不已，遂以妙演愒语，赞扬玉帝。 昔宰我、子贡、有若善称迷推尊孔子，为智足以知圣人。 今清明天主称玉帝功德如虚空，赞扬无穷尽，其他赞再无如是之切尽者，即宰我、子贡、有若之知孔子矣。 此偈可以谓之知言。 愚按：人身元神，浩劫不改，四体真主，万有之宗，妙冠六阳，慈护三元，一己真师，神气攸赖。 灵照光通，法音最上，直破迷途，示我周行，妙体玄功。 德之所被，与虚空等。 赞扬何尽？ 人不能反观内照，会此真宗，一身之至德，不识玉帝功德，又岂能知经功利益，无怪其不秘悟实体也。 清明天主仰玉帝功德，以妙偈赞，固对扬天休，亦诏人回光耳。 果能契本真，知道力，法天不私，与帝同功，自不惑他岐，弗丧天宝，至圣可希矣。 志士勖之。 神通品二十八章 是穹苍主，浩劫之尊，妙见妙知，无等无伦，湛寂真净，杳亡杳存，上圣上灵，大神通，光明藏，大丈夫，开化人天，教导无穷，大慈大悲，流焕法轮。 为度群生，是号玉皇，穹苍真老，妙圆清浄，智慧辩才，至道至尊。 开度众生，故放是光。 尔时，高虚清明天主说偈赞已，静默而坐。 魏伯阳云：高虚清明天主皈扬玉帝功德，不但有十句之赞，言此玉帝，是穹窿苍穆圣主，浩劫之至尊。 凡劫之有数，或亿或兆，皆不可言浩。 玉帝历来作万天教主，经历劫运，不可数计，广大深远，难以寻穷，故云浩劫之尊。 其遐照无遗，神通妙见，彻明无碍，大觉妙知，再无与之同等，与之比伦相类者。 莹彻虚明而湛然，巍巍不动而寂然，不二不息，其道至真，无染无沦，其德至浄。 杳若亡，非真亡，乃虚无自然； 杳若存，非执存，乃妙有无心。 杳若存亡，不可明见，难以测论矣。 仙佛诸神咸尊玉帝，是圣中最上。 万神灵通，无如玉帝。 是最上玄灵，神化六通，超绝一切。 诚大神通，普烛久照，光洁不沦，愈出愈有，无灭无晦，真光明藏，藏畜大光明无穷也。 至尊莫如道。 玉帝法道自然，最大难量，莫有止极。 允矣大丈夫，世贤以成身成性，正己物正，范围天地。 为大丈夫玉帝化天地，生民物，不见其始，莫有其终，圣中最尊，神中最大，丈夫孰甚焉。 开明孚化诸人诸天，教成启道，无有穷尽。 覆爱万有，悯念众生，永无限量。
chunks.translated_text:
One tradition states: The Jade Emperor’s conduct is truly sagely and mystically wondrous—he is the revered master of the Dao’s lineage. Heavenly and mortal beings rely upon this master. The Jade Emperor serves as the teaching lord of heaven and humanity, sovereign of all spirits, and supreme divine sage of the heavens. All people in the world revere and depend upon him, drawing upon his transformative power; thus, he is the teacher of heaven and humanity.

He expounds the Great Vehicle’s teachings,
*(The Dao’s teachings are divided into three vehicles: upper, middle, and lower. There is also a supreme vehicle, which transcends all ranks, surpassing the three grades and encompassing all without omission—this is the Great Vehicle. The teachings of various spirits follow their own wisdom and insight; the Great Vehicle is rarely heard. The Jade Emperor’s dispensation of the Dao clarifies and reveals the true essence, penetrating from highest to lowest, encompassing all grades. All beings who receive his instruction attain liberation—this is the Great Vehicle’s expounding of the Dharma.)*

He points out the true One to those lost on the path.
*(The Jade Emperor employs the true essence and the mystic principle of the One to illuminate and awaken those who have strayed, offering direct transmission without deviation, preventing them from falling into lesser or misguided teachings. It is like pointing someone toward the main road, ensuring they do not stray onto crooked paths.)*

His virtue and power are like the emptiness of space.
*(All things in the world have limits and come to an end. Only the emptiness of space remains unchanged through kalpas, never altering. The Jade Emperor’s vast merit and supreme virtue are boundless, like the emptiness of space, impossible to fathom. While other divine sages possess merit and virtue, whether great or small, near or distant, they may be compared within their own measure. The Jade Emperor’s virtue and power defy comparison—thus, they are like the emptiness of space.)*

His praises are inexhaustible.
*(The Jade Emperor’s virtue and power are like the emptiness of space; his praises cannot be fully expressed, and devotion to him knows no end. His praises are boundless, and his sublime power cannot be named. As Huang Shigong said: Though the Lord of the High Void and Pure Clarity later attended the Dharma assembly, upon truly witnessing the Jade Emperor’s wondrous transformations and divine splendor, he was filled with endless admiration. Thus, he composed sublime verses to extol the Jade Emperor. In ancient times, Zai Wo, Zigong, and You Ruo excelled in praising and revering Confucius, for their wisdom was sufficient to recognize a sage. Now, the Lord of Pure Clarity praises the Jade Emperor’s virtue and power as boundless as the emptiness of space, his praises inexhaustible—no other eulogy has been so thorough and complete. This is akin to the wisdom of Zai Wo, Zigong, and You Ruo in recognizing Confucius. These verses may truly be called "words of insight.")

My humble observation: The primordial spirit of the human body remains unchanged through kalpas; the true master of the four limbs is the origin of all existence. It wondrously crowns the six yang, compassionately protects the three origins, and serves as the true teacher of the self, upon which the spirit and qi depend. Its numinous illumination shines brightly, its Dharma voice is supreme, directly shattering delusion and revealing the all-encompassing path. Its wondrous essence and mysterious power—wherever its virtue extends, it is equal to the emptiness of space. How could praises ever be exhausted? Yet people fail to turn inward and reflect, to comprehend this true essence. They do not recognize the supreme virtue within themselves, nor the Jade Emperor’s virtue and power—how then could they grasp the benefits of this scripture’s merit? No wonder they do not awaken to the true reality.

The Lord of Pure Clarity, gazing upon the Jade Emperor’s virtue and power, composed sublime verses in praise, not only to extol the blessings of heaven but also to instruct people to turn their light inward. If one can align with their original true nature, understand the power of the Dao, and emulate heaven’s impartiality, sharing the same merit as the Emperor, they will not be misled by other paths, nor lose their celestial treasure. Thus may they aspire to sagehood. Let those of resolve take heed.

**Chapter on Spiritual Powers, Twenty-Eighth**

He is the Lord of the Vault of Heaven, honored through kalpas without end. His wondrous vision and wondrous knowledge are peerless and unmatched. Profoundly still and truly pure, he is neither gone nor present, yet both gone and present. Supreme sage, supreme spirit, great in spiritual power, repository of radiance, mighty hero—he enlightens humans and heavens, teaching without end. Vast in compassion, vast in mercy, he turns the wheel of the Dharma, delivering all beings. Thus is he named the Jade Emperor, the true elder of the vault of heaven, wondrously perfect, pure, and serene. His wisdom and eloquence, his Dao and his honor, are supreme. To liberate all beings, he emits this light.

At that time, the Lord of the High Void and Pure Clarity, having spoken his verses in praise, sat in silent meditation.

Wei Boyang said: The Lord of the High Void and Pure Clarity, in extolling the Jade Emperor’s virtue and power, not only composed ten verses of praise but also declared: This Jade Emperor is the sagely lord of the vaulted and boundless heavens, the supreme honor through kalpas without measure. *(Ordinary kalpas have numbers—whether hundreds of millions or trillions—but none can be called "vast." The Jade Emperor has served as the teaching lord of the ten thousand heavens through kalpas beyond count, vast and profound, impossible to fathom. Hence, he is called "honored through kalpas without end.")* His far-reaching illumination leaves nothing unlit; his spiritual powers and wondrous vision penetrate all without obstruction. His great awakening and mystic knowledge have no equal, no peer for comparison. Radiant and translucent, profoundly still, majestic and unshaken, he is without duality, without cessation. His Dao is utterly true; his virtue utterly pure, unstained and unsullied.

Vast as if gone—yet not truly gone, for it is the natural state of emptiness. Vast as if present—yet not clinging to presence, for it is the wondrous existence of non-attachment. Whether vast as gone or vast as present, it cannot be clearly seen or measured. All immortals, buddhas, and spirits revere the Jade Emperor as the most supreme among sages. Among all divine beings, none possess spiritual powers like his. He is the most exalted and mysterious spirit, his transformations sixfold and transcendent, surpassing all. Truly, his great spiritual power illumines eternally, his radiance pure and undimmed, ever emerging, never extinguished or obscured. He is the true repository of radiance, containing boundless great light.

None is more honored than the Dao. The Jade Emperor embodies the Dao’s spontaneity, vast beyond measure, without limit. Rightly is he called the mighty hero. *(Worldly worthies perfect body and nature, rectify themselves and others, and encompass heaven and earth—this is the mighty hero. The Jade Emperor transforms heaven and earth, gives rise to people and things, without beginning or end. Among sages, he is the most honored; among spirits, the greatest. What hero could surpass him?)* He enlightens and transforms all humans and heavens, teaching and guiding the Dao without end. He covers and loves all existence, pitying and mindful of all beings, without limit.

chunks.original_text: 信大慈大悲，转流焕明法轮，俾不滞不隐。 焕或作转，太拘了。 为化度群生，是以称号曰玉皇。 穹苍之真元老大尊，神妙圆通，真清真净，大智大慧，妙辩难穷，才施不匮，至道莫量，至尊无比。 今开化拔度众生，故放是大慈普照光明。 彼时高虚清明天主说此偈赞已，寂静默然复坐。 愚按：人身元神即上天玉帝，号曰元皇。 又曰真主，又曰玄宗，又曰祖真，又曰天君，又曰性宗，又曰真宗祖，又曰法性，又曰妙明真心，又曰正性，又曰玄灵，又曰真师，又曰玄光，又曰大柱杖，又曰法王，又曰妙宝，又曰真根，又曰佛性，又曰真种，又曰丹元。 一身真主，灵妙绝伦，明蕴无穷，开化阴阳，神智莫尽。 慈恤众妙，周应明通。 最尊最贵，化机不穷。 默融精气，以孕真灵。 故真光时露，妙机生生。 善体此者，自产神婴，与帝同功德，道化无尽矣。 契清明天主赞帝之偈，方云真知实悟耳。 不然，真妙弗得，帝化奚识。 清明偈语，诵之若梦，何以得经功，获实益？ 噫，性道在我，真妙自足。 能会妙明真机，是实对扬玉帝休光者。 神通品二十九章 於是，天尊复告四众云：是帝身即道身也，非常体也； 是无量功德之身，是清净自然之身，是神明坚固、不坏真空、无上法身。 威灵恢廓，名声周遍，无幽不烛，神妙巍巍，难可称焉。 赤脚大仙云：清明天主偈赞玉帝已，复坐默然。 於此时元始天尊复告法会上四众云：是玉帝妙化之身，即大道身也，非寻常形体也。 道本无形，何以言身？ 盖道虽虚无，无量无尽，化万有，成始终，鼓阴阳，无间息，真虚而有实体，非徒空也。 玉帝功德若虚空，与道同神，故云帝身即道身，非常体耳。 是无尽量大功德之身，是真清真浄自然不拘之身。 功有限，德有穷，难言无尽。 玉帝化一切世界，亘古不改，何有限量。 着色象、有拘滞，非清浄自然。 玉帝永无染着，得大逍遥，宁非自然。 是神通光明，坚确永固，不损坏之真空，最上无比之妙化法身。 天下之有象者悉坏，惟虚空常存。 坏者非坚固，非神明。 太虚既存，则空乃至真。 玉帝之灵通历世无损，玉帝之玄光浩劫不灭，不但至神至明，而坚不可磨，固不可破，永无毁沦，终久不坏。 是常住之真空，不消散之妙体，是无上绝伦妙法身也。 其威德灵光，岂易穷探，恢恢至弘，廓然极大，不可思议名号声称，洋溢贯彻，周遍十方。 光悉尘微，无幽不烛。 神通玄妙，巍巍莫量，荡荡难名，不可得而称焉。 愚按：人性灵明，神妙自在。 三身足，四智完，浩然之气，真一之精，万善众妙，何者不具？ 藐焉一身，参位责成，无问可息。 本非常体，乃道身，无量功德身，清浄自然身，神明坚固、不坏真空、无上法身。 何世人恣纵，虚负此身，心累神驰，精耗气散，性道不明。 谁复至命，道要茫然，幻身空尽，枉过此生，存亡若梦，一无所知，何由达化？ 问有明德尽性，或不终保其成。 所以人不能穷神达化，还虚成仙，与道合真。 至名不毁，惟玉帝以道为身，功德无量，清浄自然，神明坚固、真空不坏、无上法身。 凡初入圣流，一间未达，觑之不破，语之未悟，心思未通乎性命，不知其神之所以神，学术未贯乎天人，不知其化之所以化，委於天道之难知，希觏通玄之上士。
chunks.translated_text:
Great in faith, vast in compassion, he turns the radiant Dharma-wheel, ensuring it neither stagnates nor conceals. *(The character "fades" (焕) might also be rendered as "turns," but this would be overly restrictive.)* To transform and deliver all beings, he is thus titled the Jade Emperor.

The true primordial elder of the vaulted heavens, most venerable, wondrously all-pervasive and perfectly attuned—truly pure, truly pristine—possessing boundless wisdom and infinite discernment, his subtle eloquence inexhaustible, his talents ever-flowing, his supreme Dao immeasurable, his honor unmatched. Now, to enlighten and uplift all beings, he radiates this great compassionate light, universally illuminating.

At that moment, the Lord of the High Void and Luminous Heavens spoke this gāthā in praise, then fell silent and resumed his seat.

*(My humble note: The primordial spirit within the human body is none other than the Jade Emperor of the heavens, known as the Primordial Sovereign, the True Lord, the Mysterious Origin, the Ancestral Perfected, the Celestial Monarch, the Nature School, the True Ancestral Origin, the Dharma-nature, the Wondrous Luminous True Mind, the Right Nature, the Mysterious Numinous, the True Master, the Mysterious Radiance, the Great Pillar, the Dharma King, the Wondrous Treasure, the True Root, the Buddha-nature, the True Seed, and the Cinnabar Primordial.)*

The true lord of the body, uniquely wondrous and peerless, holds infinite luminous potential, transforming yin and yang, his divine wisdom unfathomable. Compassionate toward all subtleties, his responses are all-encompassing and luminously attuned. Most honored and most noble, his transformative power knows no end. Silently merging essence and qi, he nurtures the true numinous. Thus, the true light reveals itself at times, and the wondrous mechanism perpetually arises. Those who embody this naturally give birth to the divine infant, sharing the Jade Emperor’s merit and virtue, their Dao-transformations endless.

Only when one truly grasps the gāthā of the Lord of the Luminous Heavens in praise of the Emperor does genuine knowledge and realization arise. Otherwise, the true mystery remains unattained, and the Emperor’s transformations go unrecognized. The verses of the Luminous Gāthā, when recited, may seem like a dream—how then can one attain the merit of the scripture or reap its true benefits?

Alas! The nature of the Dao resides within us, its true mystery self-sufficient. To comprehend the wondrous luminous true mechanism is to truly respond to and extol the Jade Emperor’s glorious radiance.

**Chapter Twenty-Nine: Divine Powers**

Thereupon, the Heavenly Worthy addressed the four assemblies, saying: This Emperor’s body is the Dao-body, no ordinary form. It is the body of boundless merit and virtue, the body of true purity and spontaneity, the indestructible true emptiness of divine luminosity, the supreme Dharma-body.

His majestic spirit vast and expansive, his renown all-pervading, no darkness escapes his illumination. His divine subtlety towering and sublime, beyond all description.

The Barefoot Great Immortal said: After the Lord of the Luminous Heavens recited the gāthā in praise of the Jade Emperor, he resumed his seat in silence.

At that time, the Heavenly Worthy of Primordial Beginning again addressed the four assemblies at the Dharma assembly, saying: This wondrous transformative body of the Jade Emperor is the great Dao-body, no ordinary form.

The Dao is originally formless—how then can one speak of a "body"? Though the Dao is void and boundless, infinite and inexhaustible, it transforms the ten thousand things, completes beginnings and ends, animates yin and yang without cease. Truly empty yet possessing substance, it is not mere nothingness. The Jade Emperor’s merit and virtue are like the vastness of empty space, his spirit one with the Dao. Thus it is said: the Emperor’s body is the Dao-body, no ordinary form.

It is the body of inexhaustible great merit and virtue, the body of true purity, true clarity, and spontaneity, unbound. Merit has limits, virtue may be exhausted—how can one speak of boundlessness? The Jade Emperor transforms all worlds, unchanged since time immemorial—how could he be limited?

To be attached to form or constrained by appearances is not true purity or spontaneity. The Jade Emperor, forever free from defilement, attains great freedom—is this not spontaneity?

It is the body of divine luminosity, firm and enduring, the indestructible true emptiness, the supreme and incomparable wondrous Dharma-body. All things in the world possessing form are subject to decay—only emptiness endures. That which decays is neither firm nor divine. Since the great void abides, emptiness is the ultimate truth.

The Jade Emperor’s divine power persists through the ages undiminished, his mysterious radiance endures through kalpas unvanquished. Not only is he supremely divine and luminous, but his firmness is unassailable, his solidity unbreakable, forever immune to destruction or decay. It is the ever-abiding true emptiness, the indestructible wondrous body, the supreme and peerless Dharma-body.

Who could easily fathom his majestic virtue and divine radiance? Vast and boundless, expansive beyond measure, his inconceivable names and titles overflow, pervading the ten directions. His light reaches every mote of dust, no darkness escapes his illumination. His divine powers and mysteries towering and immeasurable, vast and indescribable—how could one ever fully extol them?

*(My humble note: The human nature is inherently luminous and divinely subtle, self-so. With the three bodies complete and the four wisdoms perfected, the vast qi of integrity, the essence of true unity, the myriad virtues and wondrous qualities—what is lacking? Yet in this fleeting body, one bears the responsibilities of the three realms, with no respite. It is no ordinary form, but the Dao-body, the body of boundless merit and virtue, the body of true purity and spontaneity, the indestructible true emptiness of divine luminosity, the supreme Dharma-body. How then do worldly people indulge themselves, squandering this body, their minds burdened and spirits scattered, essence depleted and qi dispersed, their nature and Dao obscured? Who attends to the mandate of destiny? The essentials of the Dao remain elusive. The illusory body vanishes in emptiness, this life passes in vain, existence and extinction like a dream—utterly unaware. How then can one attain transformation?)*

Some may possess luminous virtue and fulfill their nature, yet fail to preserve their attainment to the end. Thus, people cannot exhaust the divine and attain transformation, return to emptiness and become immortals, or merge with the Dao as one.

Only the Jade Emperor, whose body is the Dao, whose merit and virtue are boundless, whose purity and spontaneity are innate, whose divine luminosity is firm and indestructible, whose true emptiness is unassailable, and whose Dharma-body is supreme—his name remains imperishable.

For those newly entering the sagely stream, even a single gap remains unbridged. Gazing upon him, they cannot penetrate his mystery; speaking of him, they fail to awaken. Their minds have not yet grasped the workings of nature and destiny, nor do they understand the divine source of the divine. Their learning has not yet unified heaven and humanity, nor do they comprehend the transformative power of transformation. They resign themselves to the unfathomability of the heavenly Dao, yearning to encounter the transcendent sages who have attained the profound.

chunks.original_text: 元始怜众生之久迷，言帝德之广运，尽启世劫之聋瞶，以证神化之玄功，真大慈深仁，欲众生入妙，亦恢廓其威灵，周遍其名声，光彻幽微，神妙巍巍，德难名称。 天尊之大愿也。 奈世域漂沉，人心陷溺，不能顺帝之则，奚承元始之训？ 噫，天人一理，圣凡同心，不能希圣希天，道法自然，诚有愧於真经、大道、父母、生身已。 有志者也。 神通品三十章 是帝，非有为功德之所熏修。 而帝昔虽下生人间，多劫行化，示大神通，而身清净，未尝不在金阙分身变化，应现随方，利济群生，超升道岸，普垂教法，开悟后人，依教奉行，登真成道。 以斯功德之所庄严，是故光明常充诸天，神智妙达，莫可度量。 妙行真人云：是神妙巍巍、难可尽称之玉帝，非有作为、勉然功德之所需积修证。 是帝往昔劫前，虽下降受生於人间，多劫广行教化，显示大神通。 行化，如舍王位修行，割爱学道，行药治病，演道弘化，忍辱喜舍，位证金仙，教度菩萨等劫。 故释藏记生佛之因，言自兜率天乘香象下降於摩耶夫人腹中，遂生文佛。 是亦玉帝随方设教之一化也。 他如赴浮黎会，临宝珠会，化士庶身，化道者身，随遇着灵，普度不已，为诸天尊王，神通莫量。 是多劫行化，显示大神通，而法身清浄，巍巍不动，未尝不在黄金阙内。 方元始将说玉经，帝放大光，即分身遍十方诸大天宫。 一切世界，上天、下地、人间悉睹光明，各获利益，咸得快乐，共闻大乘。 是分身变化，应现随方，利济群生，超升道岸。 所着功德，非止一时一地，普遍垂示教法，开度觉悟后世之人，若能遵依教典，钦奉帝命，有可以位登上真，成全大道。 帝惟以此最大上妙功德之所庄严，是故所放光明常充满诸天，至神大智，灵妙通达，莫可测度思量，神智妙达，则大光明非徒尔，德盛而光妙也。 莫可度量，则神智妙达非浮尔，道妙而神彰也。 至是益见帝非有为功德之所需修矣。 愚按：人之元神，浩劫如故，大神光妙，未易名言，岂有心作为之所成哉？ 闻见觉知，行住坐卧，食息语默，应感酬醉，虽随机呈妙，清浄本体，未尝不御丹阙，即凝玄妙产神婴，而真真如如，未始他离。 千百亿化，随方利济，诞登道岸，广宣灵蕴，开化后天。 守秘持真，超凡证圣，万化悉成，无果不就。 以此妙行庄严，则一露玄光，充周莫御，性道奇验，宁可测度量计耶？ 视玉帝圣德神功，不假修为，难以量度者，不一致乎？ 惟成性虽均，而暴弃甚众，使清浄正性为淫惑障蔽，如明镜尘埋，光明不露，故妍媸不见，而妙意弗彰。 果刮垢磨光，日新月盛，应感无心，真如自在。 金阙紫府，永住元神。 常应常静，一无所扰。 妙察则一以贯万，显行则顺应无情。 慈悲大愿，永不退转，万妙庄严，难以数计。 积修无边，真光自普，功德不思议矣。 吁，此道人所固有也，非有为熏修，亦非顽空可能，不有不无。 善学者体之。 神通品三十一章 是身光明，皆具妙号。 所谓大神通光，大慈悲光，大喜舍光，大忍辱光，大平等光，大柔和光，大自在光，大利益光，大如意光，大智慧光，大吉祥光，大解脱光，大归依光，大功德光，大圆满光，大无碍光，无能胜光。 大慧真人云：是玉帝身所放大光明皆具上妙称号。
chunks.translated_text:
The Primordial Beginning took pity on sentient beings’ prolonged delusion and extolled the Emperor’s virtue as vast and far-reaching, fully awakening those deaf and blind through kalpas past to witness the wondrous efficacy of divine transformation. In true great compassion and profound benevolence, he desired all beings to enter the sublime, expanding his majestic numen and pervading his renown, illuminating the hidden and subtle, divine and wondrous, towering and boundless—his virtue defying all names. Such is the Heavenly Worthy’s great vow.

Yet the world drifts and founders, human hearts sink and drown, unable to follow the Emperor’s principles or uphold the Primordial Beginning’s teachings. Alas! Heaven and humanity share one principle, sage and mortal share one heart—failing to emulate the sage and aspire to heaven, the Dao’s law is natural, and one truly falls short before the true scriptures, the great Dao, parents, and the body of life. Such is the plight of those with resolve.

The thirty chapters on *Divine Transformations* declare: This Emperor is not one whose merit arises from cultivated deeds. Though in the past he descended to be born among humans, traversing many kalpas to enact transformation, demonstrating great divine transformations, his body remained pure and undefiled. Never did he cease residing in the Golden Palace, manifesting in myriad forms, responding to all directions, aiding and delivering sentient beings, elevating them to the Dao’s shore, universally bestowing teachings, awakening later generations. Those who follow and uphold his teachings ascend to truth and attain the Dao. Through such merit and virtue, his adornment is such that his radiance perpetually fills all heavens, his divine wisdom wondrously penetrating, beyond all measure.

The Perfected of Wondrous Conduct said: This towering, divinely wondrous Jade Emperor, whose virtues defy full enumeration, does not rely on contrived deeds or forced merit for cultivation and realization. In kalpas past, though he descended to be born among humans, traversing many kalpas to broadly enact teachings and display great divine transformations—renouncing kingship to cultivate the Dao, severing love to study the Way, administering medicines to heal illness, expounding the Dao to propagate transformation, enduring insult with joyful renunciation, attaining the rank of Golden Immortal, teaching and delivering bodhisattvas through kalpas—thus do the Buddhist scriptures record the causes of buddhas’ births, speaking of descending from Tuṣita Heaven upon a fragrant elephant into the womb of Queen Māyā, whence the Buddha of Literature was born. This, too, is but one manifestation of the Jade Emperor’s teachings, adapted to circumstances.

Elsewhere, he attended the Assembly of Floating Radiance, the Assembly of the Jeweled Pearl, assuming the forms of commoners and Daoists, wherever he encountered the numinous, universally delivering without cease. As Lord of all Heavenly Worthies, his divine transformations are immeasurable. Through many kalpas of enacting transformation and displaying great divine transformations, his Dharma-body remained pure and undefiled, towering and unshaken, never absent from the Golden Palace of Yellow and Gold.

When the Primordial Beginning was about to expound the *Jade Scripture*, the Emperor emitted a great light, instantly dividing his body to pervade the great heavenly palaces of the ten directions. In every world—above in heaven, below on earth, among humans—all beheld the radiance, each receiving benefit and joy, together hearing the Great Vehicle. Such was his division of body, transformation, and response to all directions, aiding and delivering sentient beings, elevating them to the Dao’s shore. The merit thus accrued was not confined to one time or place but universally bestowed teachings, opening and awakening later generations. Those who reverently follow the scriptures and honor the Emperor’s command may ascend to the rank of highest perfected and fulfill the great Dao.

The Emperor’s adornment with this supreme, wondrous merit is why his emitted radiance perpetually fills all heavens, his divine and great wisdom spiritually wondrous and penetrating, beyond all measurement and reckoning. His divine wisdom wondrously penetrating, his great radiance is no mere transient light—his virtue flourishes, and his light is wondrous. Beyond all measure, his divine wisdom wondrously penetrating is no fleeting attainment—his Dao is wondrous, and his divinity manifest. Thus is it ever clearer that the Emperor’s merit does not rely on cultivated deeds.

This fool observes: The primordial spirit of humans endures through kalpas unchanged; its great divine radiance and wondrousness defy easy description. How could it be achieved through intentional action? In hearing and seeing, awareness and knowing, movement and stillness, sitting and lying, eating and resting, speech and silence, responding to stimuli and reciprocating—though manifesting wondrously according to conditions, the pure original substance never departs the cinnabar palace, instantly congealing the mysterious and wondrous to produce the divine infant, while the true and real remains ever unseparated. In a hundred billion transformations, aiding and delivering according to direction, guiding beings to the Dao’s shore, broadly proclaiming the numinous essence, enlightening those of later times—guarding the secret and upholding the true, transcending the mortal and attaining the sage, all transformations reach fulfillment, no fruit left unripened. Through such wondrous conduct as adornment, a single gleam of mysterious radiance pervades all without obstruction, the marvelous efficacy of nature and Dao defying all measurement and reckoning. Behold the Jade Emperor’s sagely virtue and divine efficacy, untainted by contrivance and beyond all measure—are they not of one accord?

Though the nature of inherent perfection is shared, the reckless and abandoned are many, allowing their pure and upright nature to be obscured by lust and delusion, like a bright mirror buried in dust, its radiance unseen. Thus beauty and ugliness remain hidden, and the wondrous intent unmanifest. Yet if one scrapes away the grime and polishes the light, renewing day by day and growing month by month, responding without intention, the true and real is naturally at ease. The Golden Palace and Purple Mansion eternally house the primordial spirit, constantly responding yet constantly still, undisturbed in the least. In wondrous discernment, the one pervades the myriad; in manifest conduct, it responds without attachment. In great compassion and vast vows, it never regresses; in myriad wondrous adornments, it defies enumeration. Through boundless cultivation, true radiance naturally pervades—his merit and virtue are inconceivable.

Alas! This Dao is inherently possessed by humans, neither reliant on cultivated deeds nor attainable through stubborn emptiness, neither existent nor nonexistent. Those of discernment embody it.

The thirty-first chapter on *Divine Transformations* states: The radiance of this body bears wondrous names. They are called: Great Divine Transformation Light, Great Compassion Light, Great Joyful Renunciation Light, Great Forbearance Light, Great Equanimity Light, Great Gentleness Light, Great Freedom Light, Great Benefit Light, Great Wish-Fulfilling Light, Great Wisdom Light, Great Auspiciousness Light, Great Liberation Light, Great Refuge Light, Great Merit Light, Great Perfection Light, Great Unobstructed Light, and Invincible Light.

The Perfected of Great Wisdom said: The great radiance emitted by the Jade Emperor’s body bears these supreme and wondrous names.

chunks.original_text: 光号云何？ 所谓大神通等十七大光。 玉帝普垂照摄，妙行积证，有大威神，具六通力，神通光严，遍烛一切。 此光号第一也。 次则帝具大慈，帝具大悲，慈悲无量，光妙弘明。 大慈悲光，其二也。 再次，则帝真喜舍，喜舍无量，妙光普明，大喜舍光，其三也。 帝之累劫，又大忍辱，忍辱无边，光明莫遏。 大忍辱光，其四也。 帝之前修，行大平等，平等不已，光明莫御。 大平等光，其五也。 帝之往劫，又大柔和，柔弱安和，浩劫不改，普着光明，不可穷尽。 大柔和光，其六也。 帝德安安，超然自在，恢霁光明，终无穷极。 大自在光，是其七也。 帝仁浩浩，兼济永利，利益不穷，法辉普焕，大利益光，是其八也。 帝之普身，超证妙觉，清净自然，法王如来，又亿劫始证帝位，则最上功德，妙出无心，神化如意，如意光明，永无极已。 大如意光，是其九也。 帝有大智，帝有大慧。 智慧迈种，光明绝伦。 大智慧光，为十种矣。 帝本至善，永大吉祥。 以是光明，彻烛无息。 大吉祥光，乃十一矣。 帝夙了悟，得大解脱，脱落自然，金光永焕。 大解脱光，乃十二矣。 帝同大道，妙法自然，永劫正信，不生退转。 十方后世，悉永钦承，皈神依道，永明不晦。 大皈依光，光之十三也。 帝普度无量，曲成不遗，功德最大，光昭不匮。 大功德光，光之十四也。 功圆道备，帝德圆满，普光久丽，以其成功。 大圆满光，光之十五也。 尘染夙浄，妙通圆明，神化无碍，帝光永昭。 大无碍光，又十六号矣。 神中最贵，圣中最尊，万天主，诸佛师，浩劫法界一切无如玉帝。 是故光明常充诸界，神化莫可度量。 无能胜光，非大光明之十七乎？ 如是十七大光明神妙义，惟玉帝今见之，神通夫岂可量哉？ 愚按：人生世间，以正性为宗，故仙传实际，以此为大光明种。 但真种悉具，而保真无人，故迷惑场中，须作修洗功缘。 是以有一种最上良因，则有一等神妙光明。 玉帝积修无数，妙行难穷，不止十七良因，何为十七大光明哉？ 盖机多难悟，化繁道晦。 帝十七光明，即佛现丈六身，而顶放大祥光也。 况帝光上妙，一种超伦，孰能追踪妙行，识十七大义乎？ 噫，是难能也，亦可希也。 道本在己，怠则晦，精则明，勤修无为，不求速化，道自得之矣。 神通品三十二章 是故，汝等欲见是帝而不可得者，缘以汝等尚於身口，不舍结习，烦恼行业。 由是障故，不能得睹是帝慈颜。 吾今为汝法会众等宣示断障之法，汝等大众宜各奉行。 时诸大众不胜喜跃，各於至尊凡前称首作礼，俱欲愿闻。 雷师皓翁云：玉帝放十七大光明，神通莫量。 是故尔高虚清明天主等，欲真见是玉帝而不可得。 所以然者，缘以尔等虽无尘染，证位天帝，上妙大乘未真了彻，尚於身口不舍多劫结习、无明烦恼、凡行愆业，由是遮障之故，不能得睹见玉帝慈颜。 结习，情欲尘凡。 一切迷累本不可贪，因智慧不足，执想太重，识念一起，渐致染着，物交牵引，愈积愈深，作为结毒，致成习气。 如人以绳锁挽结，一时难解。 熏习旧染，一旦难除，恶种业根，本源未浄，习染物欲，或畜烦恼，或积愆行，或植缘业，烦杂靡定，恼乱未消，累行诸业，夙为障蔽。 今虽统御梵天，尚未彻明，弗悉重玄，奚瞻最胜，不能即见玉帝，以是故耳。
chunks.translated_text:
What are these radiant names? They refer to the seventeen great lights, beginning with Great Divine Transformation Light. The Jade Emperor universally bestows illumination and embrace; through wondrous practices and accumulated realizations, he possesses great numinous power and is endowed with the six divine penetrations. His Divine Transformation Light adorns and illumines all things—this is the first of the radiant names.

Next, the Emperor embodies great compassion, great mercy; his boundless compassion and mercy manifest in wondrous, vast radiance. Great Compassion Light is the second.

Further, the Emperor truly embodies joyful renunciation; his boundless joy and renunciation shine with wondrous, universal brightness. Great Joyful Renunciation Light is the third.

Through kalpas uncounted, the Emperor has cultivated great forbearance; his limitless forbearance emits an unstoppable radiance. Great Forbearance Light is the fourth.

In former cultivations, the Emperor practiced great equanimity; his ceaseless equanimity shines with an irresistible light. Great Equanimity Light is the fifth.

In past kalpas, the Emperor also embodied great gentleness; his tender harmony remains unchanged through vast eons, universally manifesting an inexhaustible radiance. Great Gentleness Light is the sixth.

The Emperor’s virtue is tranquil and serene, transcendent and free; his expansive, luminous radiance knows no end. Great Freedom Light is the seventh.

The Emperor’s benevolence is vast and boundless, eternally benefiting all; his unceasing beneficence shines with dharma-splendor. Great Benefit Light is the eighth.

The Emperor’s universal body has realized wondrous awakening; pure and spontaneous, he is the Dharma King, the Tathāgata. After countless kalpas, he attained the imperial throne, his supreme merit transcending thought, his numinous transformations perfectly responsive. His Wish-Fulfilling Light endures without limit. Great Wish-Fulfilling Light is the ninth.

The Emperor possesses great wisdom, great discernment; his wisdom surpasses all, his radiance peerless. Great Wisdom Light is the tenth.

The Emperor is fundamentally perfectly good, eternally supremely auspicious; his radiance shines ceaselessly. Great Auspiciousness Light is the eleventh.

The Emperor, having long awakened, attained great liberation; spontaneously released, his golden light shines forever. Great Liberation Light is the twelfth.

The Emperor is one with the great Dao, the wondrous dharma spontaneous; through endless kalpas, his true faith never wavers. All in the ten directions and future ages eternally revere and uphold him, turning their spirits to the Dao, their radiance ever bright and undimmed. Great Refuge Light is the thirteenth.

The Emperor universally delivers boundless beings, perfectly accomplishing all without omission; his merit is supreme, his radiance ever resplendent. Great Merit Light is the fourteenth.

With merit perfected and the Dao complete, the Emperor’s virtue is perfectly fulfilled; his universal light shines eternally, signifying his accomplishment. Great Perfection Light is the fifteenth.

From dust and defilement long purified, his wondrous penetration is perfectly luminous; his numinous transformations unobstructed, the Emperor’s light shines forever. Great Unobstructed Light is the sixteenth.

Noblest among spirits, most revered among sages, Lord of the Myriad Heavens, Teacher of all Buddhas—throughout the vast kalpas and dharma realms, none surpass the Jade Emperor. Thus, his radiance perpetually fills all realms, his numinous transformations immeasurable. Invincible Light—is this not the seventeenth of the great lights?

These seventeen great lights, with their wondrous and numinous meanings, are now manifested by the Jade Emperor—how could his divine transformations be measured?

This humble observer notes: In the realm of human existence, the cultivation of true nature is paramount. Thus, the *Biographies of Immortals* regard this as the seed of great radiance. Though the true seed is fully possessed, none preserve it; thus, in the realm of delusion, one must undertake the work of purification. Therefore, to each supreme good cause corresponds a wondrous, divine light. The Jade Emperor’s accumulated cultivation is immeasurable, his wondrous practices inexhaustible—why only seventeen great lights? For the faculties of beings are many and difficult to awaken, and the transformations of the Dao are profound. The Emperor’s seventeen lights are like the Buddha manifesting his thirty-two-foot form while emitting great auspicious light from his crown. Moreover, the Emperor’s light is supremely wondrous, transcending all comparison—who could trace his wondrous practices or comprehend the seventeen great meanings? Alas, this is difficult to attain, yet it may be hoped for. The Dao resides within oneself: negligence dims it, diligence brightens it. Cultivate effortless practice without seeking swift transformation, and the Dao will naturally be attained.

**Chapter Thirty-Two: Divine Transformations**

Thus, those among you who desire to behold the Emperor yet cannot do so are hindered because you remain attached to body and speech, unable to relinquish habitual tendencies, afflictive actions, and karmic deeds. Due to these obstructions, you cannot gaze upon the Emperor’s compassionate countenance. I shall now proclaim for this assembly the method to sever these hindrances; all of you should each uphold and practice it.

At that time, the great assembly was overcome with joy, each bowing their heads before the Most Revered, desiring to hear the teaching.

Master Lei, the Radiant Elder, said: The Jade Emperor emits seventeen great lights, his divine transformations immeasurable. Thus, even the Heavenly Lords of the Lofty Void and Pure Brightness, though desiring to truly behold the Jade Emperor, cannot do so. The reason is this: though you are free from dust and defilement, having realized the station of Heavenly Emperor, the supreme Mahāyāna has not been fully penetrated. You remain attached to body and speech, unable to relinquish the habitual tendencies of countless kalpas—ignorance, afflictions, and the transgressions of mundane actions. Due to these obstructions, you cannot behold the Jade Emperor’s compassionate countenance.

Habitual tendencies arise from worldly desires and defilements. All delusive entanglements must not be coveted; yet, due to insufficient wisdom and excessive attachment, thoughts arise, gradually leading to contamination. Entangled by external objects, the bonds deepen, forming toxic habits like ropes tightly knotted, difficult to untie in an instant. Long-ingrained defilements are not easily removed; the roots of evil karma remain unpurified. Habitual tendencies toward worldly desires may accumulate afflictions, transgressive actions, or karmic conditions—endless distractions, unceasing disturbances, and the burdens of past deeds obscure and obstruct. Though you now govern the Brahmā heavens, your realization remains incomplete, the profound mystery not fully grasped. How then could you behold the Most Supreme? Thus, you cannot immediately see the Jade Emperor.

chunks.original_text: 吾今为尔法会众等，宣明显示断除障滞之法。 汝等大众宜各奉持躬行。 时诸大众，不胜欢喜踊跃，各於元始玉几前稽首俯悤页，恭敬作礼，俱欲愿闻断障秘论。 吾，元始自谓也。 几，案也。 愚按：人之生来，各有夙因。 虽元会初开，太和之气，而往劫修习亦难顿忘。 故经以夙含业缘比之积毒，诚有见也。 是以有喜缘者，则异域同心，为恶缘者，则对面千里。 莫言《道藏》功案、释教录记，或指为异端之论，即儒书中，晏婴之沮孔子，先正归之命。 程、苏大儒，分为蜀、洛之党，此亦缘之不偶也。 而相须之殷，不免於相遇之疏，今古同以为恨。 则因缘之说，岂可尽废哉？ 用是十识难尽，五蕴难穷，十有三徒，二十五魔种，七假三合，一切机括，谁复易逃。 清明天主证帝位为尊神，虽脱尘染，浩劫夙积，未尽超融，境落高虚，号着清明。 往昔善因，未脱虚无套矣。 虚明妙有如玉帝者，岂能遽见。 释经考菩萨行，尚有睹面不见释迦如来，文佛演最上义，菩萨默默以听，亦此义也。 至圣岂易见，身口结习之障岂易消耶？ 然此理最难看，见帝，非面见； 了知帝行，彻契帝德。 如在孔子之门，真得宣圣传授心法者，一机。 心若孚，则时异世殊，其揆一也。 神交心会，其见乃真。 兹聪明颜子，尚未达一间； 清明天主不能睹玉帝，又何疑？ 元始断阵之法，莹明夙行，了验心宗，捍格既融，外有何障，见玉帝矣。 所以众欲乐闻。 吁，起障破阵，一切由心。 大通无碍，自己元神，对越不怠； 口耳粗迹，弗为滞障，大道不在我乎？ 勉之。 神通品三十三章 天尊言曰：断障之法，当生大慧，无起疑惑，无起贪瞋，无起媱欲，无起嫉妬，无起杀害，无起凡情，无起凡思，无起昏垢，无起声色，无起是非，无起憎爱，无起分别，无起高慢，无起执着。 广成子云：元始天尊因清众请问无障妙旨，遂言曰：断除障碍，得睹见玉帝妙化光颜，其道无他，当生神智大慧，笃信正道，无起疑贰惑乱之心。 大道至正，真一不二，本无可疑惑。 明不足以察具几，遂至持两端，无定见，魔知通从。 既知大道在我，知明守固，勿贰以二，勿参以三，更何疑焉？ 不疑则无惑，道可从入。 故断障融净结习之大慧，必先无起疑惑。 求道者不可计功，亦不可以他求，嗔怒忿怨不平之心俱不可有。 断障之次，无起贪嗔，心专於道，其衷自然。 滋私长欲，妄念易生，纤毫淫逸嗜欲之意皆大乱真。 断障之三，无起媱欲。 道无所不容，贤不肖皆吾之师友。 若丝毫忌刻贤能，或厌恶庸愚，皆为大非。 断障之四，无起嫉妬，大道至仁，一不忍伤。 若因逆恶，触萌剪灭之心，背道亦甚。 断障之五，无起杀害。 《阴符》虽言杀机，只是说能照伏邪魔，则至真自在。 若秋天肃杀，而草木归根，生机敛人，见天地之仁处，非世所谓杀也。 又云：恩生於害。 亦复其见天地之心意耳，非世所谓害也。 大道无为，情识不用。 一动凡意，其谬无穷。 断障之六，无起凡情。 大道志机，诸想须净。 一有尘思，其弊无边。 断障之七，无起凡思。 道本贞明，清净无染。 少涉昏昧尘垢，丧我至真矣。 断障之八，无起昏垢。 道无声臭。 以声色求之，去道远矣。 体道者，不惟外面声色不碍，与世无干，道之影响畔岸，一切不求不执。
chunks.translated_text:
Here now do I, for this assembly of disciples, clearly expound and reveal the method to sever and dissolve all obstructions. Let each among you uphold and practice it with utmost devotion.

At that moment, the great assembly overflowed with joy and exultation, each prostrating before the Jade Table of the Primordial Beginning, bowing their heads in reverence, eager to hear the esoteric discourse on severing obstructions.

I—this is the self-designation of the Primordial Beginning. *Table*—a desk or stand.

I observe: since birth, each person carries karmic conditions from former lives. Though the kalpas renew and the qi of Great Harmony prevails, the cultivation of past eons is not easily forgotten at once. Thus, the scriptures compare the latent karmic affinities to accumulated toxins—truly an insightful analogy. Those bound by auspicious affinities may meet as kindred spirits across distant lands, while those entangled in malevolent affinities may remain as strangers though face-to-face. Do not dismiss the records of the *Daoist Canon* or the annals of Buddhist teachings as heterodox doctrines; even within Confucian texts, Yan Ying’s opposition to Confucius was attributed to fate, and the great scholars Cheng and Su were divided into the factions of Shu and Luo—such too is the misfortune of ill-matched affinities. Yet those who ought to be close may grow distant over time, a lament shared across ages. How then can the doctrine of karmic conditions be entirely abandoned?

Thus, the ten perceptions are not easily exhausted, the five aggregates not easily fathomed. The thirteen kinds of disciples, the twenty-five demonic seeds, the seven illusions and three unions—all these mechanisms and snares, who can easily escape? The Lord of the Pure Bright Heaven, though enthroned as a supreme deity and freed from worldly defilements, has not yet transcended the accumulated karma of countless kalpas, lingering in the lofty void, styled the Pure and Bright. Past virtuous causes have not yet shed the trappings of emptiness. How then could one such as the Jade Emperor, who embodies the wondrous existence of empty luminosity, be readily perceived?

In examining the sutras and the bodhisattva path, even those who beheld the face of Śākyamuni Tathāgata did not truly see him. When the Buddha of Measureless Light expounded the supreme truth, the bodhisattvas listened in silence—such is the meaning here. How easily can the Most Sagely be seen? How easily can the obstructions of bodily and verbal habits be dissolved?

Yet this principle is most difficult to perceive: to *see* the Emperor is not to see with the eyes; to fully comprehend the Emperor’s conduct is to thoroughly align with his virtue. As among Confucius’ disciples, only those who truly received the Master’s transmission of the heart-mind attained the one mechanism. When the heart is sincere, though times and worlds differ, the principle remains the same. Only through spiritual communion and heart-mind resonance is true vision attained. Even the wise Yan Hui fell short by a single degree; how then should the Lord of the Pure Bright Heaven, unable to behold the Jade Emperor, be doubted?

The method of the Primordial Beginning to sever the demonic array is to illumine past deeds, verify the heart’s essence, and dissolve all barriers. Once inner obstructions are melted away, what external hindrance remains? Then the Jade Emperor may be seen. Thus, the assembly yearned to hear these teachings.

Alas! The arising of obstructions and the breaking of demonic arrays—all proceed from the mind. With great penetration and unimpeded freedom, one’s original spirit responds without negligence. The coarse traces of speech and hearing must not become stagnant obstructions. Is not the Great Dao within me? Strive on!

**Chapter Thirty-Three: The Divine Penetrations**
The Heavenly Worthy spoke:
The method to sever obstructions is to generate great wisdom. Do not arouse doubt, do not arouse greed or anger, do not arouse sensual desire, do not arouse jealousy, do not arouse killing or harm, do not arouse mundane emotions, do not arouse mundane thoughts, do not arouse dullness or defilement, do not arouse sound or form, do not arouse right or wrong, do not arouse love or hatred, do not arouse discrimination, do not arouse arrogance, do not arouse attachment.

Guangchengzi said: When the assembly of the pure requested the Primordial Heavenly Worthy to expound the wondrous principle of obstruction-free vision, he declared: To sever obstructions and behold the wondrous transformation and radiant countenance of the Jade Emperor, there is no other way—one must generate the divine wisdom of the spirit-mind, firmly believe in the true Dao, and not arouse the heart of doubt, duality, or confusion.

The Great Dao is utterly correct, the True One without duality—there is fundamentally nothing to doubt. Yet when clarity is insufficient to perceive the subtleties, one wavers between two extremes, lacking steadfast vision, and demonic knowledge infiltrates. Once you know the Great Dao resides within you, guard this knowing with firmness. Do not divide it into two, do not multiply it into three—what then is there to doubt? Without doubt, there is no confusion, and the Dao may be entered.

Thus, the great wisdom that severs obstructions and dissolves ingrained habits must first be free of doubt. Seekers of the Dao must not calculate merit, nor seek it elsewhere. Anger, resentment, indignation, and discontent—none of these may arise.

Next in severing obstructions: do not arouse greed or anger. With the heart focused on the Dao, its center remains naturally pure. Nurturing private desires and indulging in excess easily gives rise to deluded thoughts; even the slightest inclination toward sensual indulgence or craving greatly disrupts the truth.

Third in severing obstructions: do not arouse sensual desire. The Dao embraces all without exception; the worthy and the unworthy alike are my teachers and friends. Even the slightest envy of the worthy or disdain for the mediocre is a grave error.

Fourth in severing obstructions: do not arouse jealousy. The Great Dao is supremely benevolent, not tolerating even the slightest harm. If, due to adversity or malice, one harbors thoughts of eradication, this is a grave departure from the Dao.

Fifth in severing obstructions: do not arouse killing or harm. Though the *Yinfu Jing* speaks of the mechanism of killing, it refers only to the ability to subdue and restrain demonic forces, whereby true freedom is attained. As in autumn’s solemn withering, when grasses and trees return to their roots, life’s mechanism withdraws—here lies the benevolence of Heaven and Earth, not the killing of the mundane world. It is also said: “Blessing arises from harm.” This too reveals the intent of Heaven and Earth, not the harm of the mundane world.

Sixth in severing obstructions: do not arouse mundane emotions. The Great Dao is without action; worldly perceptions and knowledge are not employed. The slightest activation of mundane intent leads to endless error.

Seventh in severing obstructions: do not arouse mundane thoughts. The mechanism of the Great Dao requires all thoughts to be purified. The slightest trace of worldly thinking brings boundless harm.

Eighth in severing obstructions: do not arouse dullness or defilement. The Dao is fundamentally pure and luminous, free from contamination. The slightest touch of dullness or worldly filth loses one’s utmost truth.

The Dao is without sound or scent. To seek it through sound or form is to distance oneself from the Dao. Those who embody the Dao are not only unobstructed by external sounds and forms, untouched by worldly affairs, but also free from all traces and boundaries of the Dao—nothing is sought, nothing is grasped.

Thus, you cannot immediately see the Jade Emperor.
